plugin.sh: Add the installing solum-dashboard

Add the installing solum-dashboard in plugin.sh for DevStack

Change-Id: I0455afa5f209e410c2bbb126beb89fd45feba3f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/97/277197/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: GITREPO["solum-dashboard"]=${SOLUMDASHBOARD_REPO:-${GIT_BASE}/openstack/solum-dashboard.git} GITBRANCH["solum-dashboard"]=${SOLUMDASHBOARD_BRANCH:-master} GITDIR["solum-dashboard"]=$DEST/solum-dashboard function install_solum_dashboard() { git_clone_by_name "solum-dashboard" setup_dev_lib "solum-dashboard" ln -s $DEST/solum-dashboard/_50_solum.py.example $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled/_50_solum.py restart_apache_server } function cleanup_solum_dashboard() { rm $HORIZON_DIR/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled/_50_solum.py } if is_service_enabled horizon; then echo_summary "Installing Solum Dashboard" install_solum_dashboard fi if is_service_enabled horizon; then echo_summary "Cleaning Solum Dashboard up" cleanup_solum_dashboard fi

commit_message:
Don't disallow quota deletion if allocated < 0

Due to the race condition http://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1552944,
it's possible that a volume delete on a project at the same time as a
change to/from a -1 limit on the project could double count the change
in allocated value. This has the possibility to set allocated < 0, and
in order to handle this situation as gracefully as possible, we should
not disallow quota deletion in the case that allocated < 0.

Change-Id: Ic35ff9671024aa1cecc04b205d1b7cba56bbea61
Closes-Bug: #1554173

commit_message:
[Docker] Do not try to delete container on destroyed host

When Environment get deleted both Docker/k8s host and
Docker applications get deleted. So it is possible that host
will try to delete container from an Instance that was already
destroyed. Attempt to send commands to such instance
will hang until timeout because there is no more agent
exist on the other side.

Change-Id: Ia6e8064ae50c24ce595ed08e446ed45b96b4a330
Closes-Bug: #1504623
Depends-On: I298f3f079a153ef87ed7213b7f1432c9e5e4b4b6

commit_message:
Deduplicated error messages regarding invalid names

One error message was not exactly the same, but the code also
checked for a leading alpha-numeric. So I fixed that message.

Closes-Bug: #1579240

Change-Id: Iebd73af7a9ec1f6df90f1559659931782c7d5ec5

commit_message:
Fix default route for multi-rack

Port logic from configure_default_route.pp task to netconfig.pp
in order to not break configuration on multi-rack envs.

Change-Id: I20ffd495122de3caab3da12f1b6fcee6f23bc16f
Closes-bug: #1584002

We can do this when we deprecate role-based deployment. # Meanwhile returning empty hash is still needed for post deployment # configure_default_route task for mongo roles. $network_scheme = empty($new_network_scheme) ? { default => $loaded_network_scheme, false => $new_network_scheme }

commit_message:
Introduce libvirt power/mgmt driver

Libvirt has its own API. It allows to connect to different hypervisors
like xen, vmware, virtualbox, qemu, full list can be found at
https://libvirt.org/drivers.html.
It supports different type of transports like ssh, tcp, unix sockets.

This patch introduces new type of power and management drivers `*_libvirt`,
which use libvirt-python library to connect to hypervisor.

Corresponding DevStack plugin changes allowing to deploy DevStack with
this new driver are also added.

Depends-On: Ib3e8b41202f56ea1f5efd83b28932eb8edcbbbc3
Change-Id: Id4bc7f1a2f20936a02395f0f2147381b4649beea
Closes-Bug: #1523880
Closes-Bug: #1527221

commit_message:
Network isolation for virtualized environments

Add some docs to describe, in as few steps as possible, how
developers using virtualized environments can enable network
isolation.

Change-Id: I458d91bc9b1079d899ac7c1be52296078845c9a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/91/293091/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Configuring Network Isolation in Virt Environments ================================================== Introduction ------------ This document describes how to configure a virtualized development environment for use with network isolation. To make things as easy as possible we will use the 'single-nic-with-vlans' network isolation templates to create isolated Vlans on top of the single NIC already used for the provisioning/ctlplane. Single nic vlans works well for many virtualized environments because it doesn't require adding any extra NICs. Additionally, Openvswitch automatically trunks vlans for us so there is no extra switch configuration required. Create an external Vlan on your Undercloud ------------------------------------------ By default all instack undercloud machines have a br-ctlplane which is used as the provisioning network. We want to add an interface on the 10.0.0.0/24 network which is used as the default "external" (public) network for the overcloud. The default vlan for the external network is vlan10 so we create an interface file to do this. Create the following file /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-vlan10:: DEVICE=vlan10 ONBOOT=yes HOTPLUG=no TYPE=OVSIntPort OVS_BRIDGE=br-ctlplane OVS_OPTIONS="tag=10" BOOTPROTO=static IPADDR=10.0.0.1 PREFIX=24 NM_CONTROLLED=no And then run 'ifup vlan10' on your undercloud. Create a custom environment file: --------------------------------- When using network isolation most of the network/config templates configure static IPs for the ctlplane. To ensure connectivity with Heat and Ec2 metadata we need to specify a couple of extra heat parameters. Create a file called /home/stack/custom.yaml with the following:: parameter_defaults: EC2MetadataIp: 192.0.2.1 ControlPlaneDefaultRoute: 192.0.2.1 Modify your overcloud deploy to enable network isolation: --------------------------------------------------------- At this point we are ready to create the overcloud using the network isolation defaults. The command below demonstrates how to enable network isolation by using heat templates for network isolation, a custom set of network config templates (single nic vlans), and our custom.yaml config file from above:: TEMPLATES=/usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/ openstack overcloud deploy \ --templates=$TEMPLATES \ -e $TEMPLATES/environments/network-isolation.yaml \ -e $TEMPLATES/environments/net-single-nic-with-vlans.yaml \ -e /home/stack/custom.yaml After creating the stack you should now have a working virtualized development environment with network isolation enabled.

commit_message:
Specify one more group for detach-rabbitmq tests for the plugin CI

We want to test detach-rabbitmq on Plugin CI. To do that, we need to
outline a set of tests we want to run on each commit. That is done with
the new 'detach-rabbitmq-ci-group' group, covering a couple of already
existing test cases. The group is intended for Plugin CI use only.

Change-Id: Ia75a39f1a3e889f4635909fdb52d993fcb11974d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/35/320435/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Package updates deprecation fixes

- Fix react v15 - uncontrollable/controllable components in Formsy forms
  https://github.com/christianalfoni/formsy-react/issues/332
- Use replace instead of replaceState, update 'location' usage
- Remove key as prop
- Remove unused packages
- Remove dispatchers

Change-Id: I990446becd647293e60fe508d27ca9684e4477db

commit_message:
Use JUJU_MODEL_UUID for Juju 2.0

Juju 2.0 renames the environment variable JUJU_ENV_UUID
to JUJU_MODEL_UUID; use this environment variable as a
fallback if JUJU_ENV_UUID is not set to support Juju 2.0,
whilst continuing to provide support for Juju < 2.0.

Change-Id: I0e9ebbe59032e3d15864ee1f9bd49b404b339a3b
Closes-Bug: 1572575

commit_message:
Make user possible to specify which node disk is bootable

"Boot from" checkboxes added to node disks screen. Disk might be
selected as bootable, as well as deselected. If no disk selected as
bootable it's up to system to decide which one to use as bootable.

Change-Id: I387a3ce2aaa6e7927ae9518e515a818fc23f12e2
Partial-Bug: #1567450

commit_message:
[Reports] Introduce class processing.plot.Trends

This class is for processing tasks results and generating
data for upcoming trends report.

It will be actually in use in further patches.

Blueprint: trends-report
Change-Id: I6f7d028b0f64d4d5ff6d6c3b7684f16a0344b169

subject: Change Metadata Display widget to case insensitive
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-18 22:15:02.000000000', 'files': ['horizon/static/framework/widgets/metadata/tree/tree.service.js', 'horizon/static/framework/widgets/metadata/tree/tree.spec.js'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/cdde60c315335c74eda9e0d7eb809da10a73855c', 'message': 'Change Metadata Display widget to case insensitive

The metadata-display should match properties using case insensitive.
I've found that if you pass in extra metadata properties to
Glance v1 at create time, it takes all the properties and stores
them as lower case. So when you create an image with metadata of
FOO=BAR, it will store as foo=bar.

There are some properties "CIM_PASD_InstructionSet" that when
create at the same time as creating the image get changed to
cim_pasd_instructionset". When this gets subsequently retrieved
from Glance and displayed in the metadata-display widget,
it doesn't recognize them and won't show them.

To test, you need: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/236042/

Create an Image using the CIM Instruction Set metadata.

Go to image row and expand. You won't see the metadata.

Apply this patch git review -x 315295

Then do the same steps.  You'll see the metadata displayed:

http://imgur.com/eMfLd9H

Change-Id: I5127283e90505f3580af6afea3eb992a91b8dfc8
Closes-Bug: 1580790
(cherry picked from commit 802ec1f77a2c4aa40804d2f1e46cdc28a757f6d6)
'}]
commit_message:
Change Metadata Display widget to case insensitive

The metadata-display should match properties using case insensitive.
I've found that if you pass in extra metadata properties to
Glance v1 at create time, it takes all the properties and stores
them as lower case. So when you create an image with metadata of
FOO=BAR, it will store as foo=bar.

There are some properties "CIM_PASD_InstructionSet" that when
create at the same time as creating the image get changed to
cim_pasd_instructionset". When this gets subsequently retrieved
from Glance and displayed in the metadata-display widget,
it doesn't recognize them and won't show them.

To test, you need: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/236042/

Create an Image using the CIM Instruction Set metadata.

Go to image row and expand. You won't see the metadata.

Apply this patch git review -x 315295

Then do the same steps.  You'll see the metadata displayed:

http://imgur.com/eMfLd9H

Change-Id: I5127283e90505f3580af6afea3eb992a91b8dfc8
Closes-Bug: 1580790
(cherry picked from commit 802ec1f77a2c4aa40804d2f1e46cdc28a757f6d6)

commit_message:
Add ability to manage several environments at once in dashboard

Patch makes it possible for user to select several environments and
execute one of the three actions to them: delete, abandon or
deploy.
Tests to check new functionality are added.

Change-Id: I2b395cc2ed80a59d39eb984c920f83ac6b687572
Closes-bug: #1582193

added_lines: table_actions = (CreateEnvironment, DeployEnvironment, DeleteEnvironment, AbandonEnvironment) #multi_select = False

commit_message:
Remove "periodic_interval" config option

This was deprecated February 24, 2016. It's time to remove it.

Change-Id: If82a6a2c94b22ddcd8707bc8bd7f73ecaa24e021

commit_message:
Fix up RPC cleanup process

We don't need to assert here, because we will
throw exceptions when using TRANSPORT and
NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT if they are None.

If NOTIFIER is None, log an exception and continue,
since it is not used here.

This still allows detection of problems like the
asserts did, but will not fail needlessly.

Change-Id: I6f0c3ce19a60339e926946b605962d4121a06d8e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/95/316895/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.i18n import _LE, _LI if NOTIFIER is None: LOG.exception(_LE("RPC cleanup: NOTIFIER is None"))
deleted_lines: from cinder.i18n import _LI assert TRANSPORT is not None assert NOTIFICATION_TRANSPORT is not None assert NOTIFIER is not None

commit_message:
Use 'trimmed' for blocktrans with multi-line contents

blocktrans trimmed option removes newlines from contents of blocktrans
and replaces any whitespace at the beginning and end of a line into
a single space. This makes translator life easier.
More detail is described in the bug report.

Closes-Bug: #1583757
Depends-On: I534895be0d5f4bf0429b1511ee5421991386c873
Change-Id: Idb451b7688fd5533a8315399de13bac8b8078a67
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/96/318896/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {% blocktrans trimmed %}

commit_message:
Add support for FICON attached ECKD volumes for Linux on System z

This spec describes required changes to support FICON attached ECKD
volumes.

Implements: blueprint linux-ficon-support

Change-Id: Ib64b7d952b125445b0a38b693256987a2da8bfcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/21/302221/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================ Support ECKD volumes on Linux on System z ================================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/linux-ficon-support FICON (Fibre Connection) is a Fibre-Channel FC-4 layer protocol. It is used on mainframes to attach ECKD volumes via Fibre-Channel. Several changes are needed in order to allow Cinder to manage FICON-based block storage on Linux on System z. Besides, support is to be added to the existing Cinder drivers for storage subsystems supporting ECKD (for example, IBM DS8000). Required support in Nova is described by a separate blueprint which is listed as a dependency below. Problem description =================== FICON and FCP are Fibre-Channel FC-4 layer protocols. FICON uses a different scheme to address volumes, compared to FCP. * ECKD volumes are addressed by a Control Unit and Unit Address, rather than WWPN and LUN. * System z uses a different format for device file paths (ccw-based, rather than pci-based), similar to the file paths used for FCP on System z * ECKD volumes need to be set online and formatted before they can be used Proposed change =============== Change code in os-brick to address these issues, dependent on a new protocol type of 'fibre_channel_eckd', provided by the driver For details, see section `Work Items`. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Platforms that support FICON/ECKD will need to implement this for their drivers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stefan-amann Other contributors: mzoeller maiera Work Items ---------- In ``os-brick/initiator/connector.py``: * provide a new connector FibreChannelECKDConnector * connect_volume needs to enable interrupts for the volume and set the volume online. This is done by calling the new configure_eckd_device() function) * disconnect_volume needs to set the volume offline. This is done by calling the new deconfigure_eckd_device() function In ``os-brick/initiator/linuxeckd.py``: * Utility functions to set the volume online, validate it is formatted appropriately, and format it if required :: def _is_online(self, device): """ Return True if device is online, else return False :param device: device id """ if os.access('/sys/bus/ccw/devices/%s/online' % device, os.R_OK): online_file = None try: online_file = open('/sys/bus/ccw/devices/%s/online' % device) value = online_file.readline() if value and value.strip() == '1': return True finally: if online_file: online_file.close() return False def _is_formatted(self, device): """ Return True if device is online, else return False :param device: device id """ if os.access('/sys/bus/ccw/devices/%s/status' % device, os.R_OK): formatted = None (out, _err) = self._execute('cat', '/sys/bus/ccw/devices/%s/status' % device, run_as_root=True, root_helper=self._root_helper) if out and out.strip() == 'unformatted': return False return True def format_eckd_volume(self, path): """ formats ECKD volume :param device: device path """ name = os.path.realpath(path) if name.startswith("/dev/"): format_cmd = 'dasdfmt -y -b 4096 -d ldl ' + name (out, _err) = self._execute(format_cmd, run_as_root=True, root_helper=self._root_helper) return True else: return False In ``os-brick/initiator/linuxfc.py``: * new class LinuxFibreChannelECKD :: def configure_eckd_device(self, device_number): """Add the eckd volume to the Linux configuration. """ full_device_identifier = "0.0.%04x" % device_number eckd_device_command = ('cio_ignore', '-r', '%(dev_id)s' % {"dev_id": full_device_identifier}) LOG.debug("issue cio_ignore for s390: %s", eckd_device_command) out, info = None, None try: out, info = self._execute('cio_ignore', '-r', '%(dev_id)s' % {"dev_id": full_device_identifier}, run_as_root=True, root_helper=self._root_helper) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: LOG.warning(_LW("cio_ignore call for s390 failed exit" " %(code)s, stderr %(stderr)s"), {'code': exc.exit_code, 'stderr': exc.stderr}) eckd_device_command = ('chccwdev', '-e', '%(dev_id)s' % {"dev_id": full_device_identifier}) LOG.debug("add ECKD command for s390: %s", eckd_device_command) out, info = None, None try: out, info = self._execute('chccwdev', '-e', '%(dev_id)s' % {"dev_id": full_device_identifier}, run_as_root=True, root_helper=self._root_helper) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: LOG.warning(_LW("add ECKD call for s390 failed exit" " %(code)s, stderr %(stderr)s"), {'code': exc.exit_code, 'stderr': exc.stderr}) def deconfigure_eckd_device(self, device_number): """Remove the eckd volume from the Linux configuration. """ LOG.debug("Deconfigure ECKD volume for s390: device_number=%(device_num)s ", {'device_num': device_number}) full_device_identifier = "0.0.%04x" % device_number eckd_device_command = ('chccwdev', '-d', '%(dev_id)s' % {"dev_id": full_device_identifier}) LOG.debug("remove ECKD command for s390: %s", eckd_device_command) out, info = None, None try: out, info = self._execute('chccwdev', '-d', '%(dev_id)s' % {"dev_id": full_device_identifier}, run_as_root=True, root_helper=self._root_helper) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: LOG.warning(_LW("remove ECKD call for s390 failed exit" " %(code)s, stderr %(stderr)s"), {'code': exc.exit_code, 'stderr': exc.stderr}) Adaptations to volume.filters to allow the new commands to be sent Cinder drivers need to report the Control Unit address, and Unit Address of the ECKD volume and set the driver_volume_type to 'fibre_channel_eckd' Dependencies ============ Nova blueprint to add support for ECKD for Linux on System z Testing ======= Unit test: * Unit tests will be added and performed on System z, as well as Intel-based machines. Documentation Impact ==================== * We will update documentation as required. References ========== * _`[1]` Linux on System z Device Driver book, http://public.dhe.ibm.com/software/dw/linux390/docu/l316dd25.pdf * _`[2]` Linux on System z, http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/linux390/

subject: [Verify] Correctly configure auth URLs and auth version
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 13:08:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/4a4e0da6d478ff9db3eb3cff2c9420dbff8a3a43', 'message': '[Verify] Correctly configure auth URLs and auth version

When we have an auth URL, for example, like this http://127.0.0.1:5000/,
Rally fails to correctly configure the following tempest options:
auth_version, uri and uri_v3 and we may encounter the following error:

    InvalidConfiguration: Invalid Configuration
    Details: Unsupported auth version:

because of not correctly configured options:

auth_version =
uri = http://10.109.6.7:5000/
uri_v3 = http:/v3/v310.109.6.7:5000/v3

It should be

auth_version = v2
uri = http://10.109.6.7:5000/v2.0
uri_v3 = http://10.109.6.7:5000/v3

instead.

Change-Id: Ifddd4667f0cce06d07a8a002d4bb3bd97deaf200
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-23 13:11:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/e85cb6e6d439da2804312576c4b102a4e61fa371', 'message': '[Verify] Correctly configure auth URLs and auth version

When we have an auth URL, for example, like this http://127.0.0.1:5000/,
Rally fails to correctly configure the following tempest options:
auth_version, uri and uri_v3 and we may encounter the following error:

    InvalidConfiguration: Invalid Configuration
    Details: Unsupported auth version:

because of not correctly configured options:

auth_version =
uri = http://10.109.6.7:5000/
uri_v3 = http:/v3/v310.109.6.7:5000/v3

It should be

auth_version = v2
uri = http://10.109.6.7:5000/v2.0
uri_v3 = http://10.109.6.7:5000/v3

instead.

Change-Id: Ifddd4667f0cce06d07a8a002d4bb3bd97deaf200
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-05-23 13:19:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/c1cddfb943d7d36e3ae0684db7d430552a8eb4ae', 'message': '[Verify] Correctly configure auth URLs and auth version

When we have an auth URL, for example, like this http://127.0.0.1:5000/,
Rally fails to correctly configure the following tempest options:
auth_version, uri and uri_v3 and we may encounter the following error:

    InvalidConfiguration: Invalid Configuration
    Details: Unsupported auth version:

because of not correctly configured options:

    auth_version =
    uri = http://127.0.0.1:5000/
    uri_v3 = http:/v3/v3127.0.0.1:5000/v3

It should be

    auth_version = v2
    uri = http://10.109.6.7:5000/v2.0
    uri_v3 = http://10.109.6.7:5000/v3

instead.

Tempest needs /v2.0 and /v3 at the end of URLs.

Change-Id: Ifddd4667f0cce06d07a8a002d4bb3bd97deaf200
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-05-23 13:19:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/1905668684e5009d350d4ace033076fa0bfafe9c', 'message': '[Verify] Correctly configure auth URLs and auth version

When we have an auth URL, for example, like this http://127.0.0.1:5000/,
Rally fails to correctly configure the following tempest options:
auth_version, uri and uri_v3 and we may encounter the following error:

    InvalidConfiguration: Invalid Configuration
    Details: Unsupported auth version:

because of not correctly configured options:

    auth_version =
    uri = http://127.0.0.1:5000/
    uri_v3 = http:/v3/v3127.0.0.1:5000/v3

It should be

    auth_version = v2
    uri = http://127.0.0.1:5000/v2.0
    uri_v3 = http://127.0.0.1:5000/v3

instead.

commit_message:
[Verify] Correctly configure auth URLs and auth version

When we have an auth URL, for example, like this http://127.0.0.1:5000/,
Rally fails to correctly configure the following tempest options:
auth_version, uri and uri_v3 and we may encounter the following error:

    InvalidConfiguration: Invalid Configuration
    Details: Unsupported auth version:

because of not correctly configured options:

    auth_version =
    uri = http://127.0.0.1:5000/
    uri_v3 = http:/v3/v3127.0.0.1:5000/v3

It should be

    auth_version = v2
    uri = http://127.0.0.1:5000/v2.0
    uri_v3 = http://127.0.0.1:5000/v3

instead.

Tempest needs /v2.0 and /v3 at the end of URLs.

Change-Id: Ifddd4667f0cce06d07a8a002d4bb3bd97deaf200
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/25/319925/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: auth_url = self.credential["auth_url"] if "/v2" not in auth_url and "/v3" not in auth_url: url_path = "/v2.0" auth_url = parse.urljoin(auth_url, url_path) else: url_path = parse.urlparse(auth_url).path self.conf.set(section_name, "auth_version", url_path[1:3]) self.conf.set(section_name, "uri", auth_url) auth_url.replace(url_path, "/v3"))

commit_message:
Use region from config in functional tests

We seem to be using hardcoded region in some inline
templates of fucntional tests. They would fail if
the region name is different. This changes to use
it from the config.

Change-Id: Iafd1251545e00c6cba292b042352b1ef34da81e0
Closes-Bug: #1560585
(cherry picked from commit cbed62355cb006dabd6a160f4c9f04d423a353c0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/97/320397/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # replacing the template region with the one from the config self.template = self.template.replace('RegionOne', self.conf.region) tmpl_bad_region = self.template.replace(self.conf.region, 'DARKHOLE') 'endpoint at region "%s" due to ' '"ERROR: The template section is ' 'invalid: resource"') % self.conf.region
deleted_lines: tmpl_bad_region = self.template.replace('RegionOne', 'DARKHOLE') 'endpoint at region "RegionOne" due to ' '"ERROR: The template section is invalid: resource"')

commit_message:
Fix tests for concat 2.1.0

Depends-On: I8e3cd60fa50e04221aedf5c153c1ecb8a5bd97b5

Change-Id: I920479f9d5f0d94151c63a5fdc1445edf984a01a
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/40/319140/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
it do is_expected.to contain_concat_fragment('swift_account_quotas').with_content("
[filter:account_quotas]
use = egg:swift#account_quotas
")
deleted_lines: let :facts do {} let :pre_condition do 'concat { "/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf": }' end let :fragment_file do "/var/lib/puppet/concat/_etc_swift_proxy-server.conf/fragments/80_swift_account_quotas" end it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/\[filter:account_quotas\]/) } it { is_expected.to contain_file(fragment_file).with_content(/use = egg:swift#account_quotas/) }

commit_message:
Make configurable the location where config files are merged

An operator may want to specify the location of custom config
files so that kolla can detect their location and merge
them with the default configs generated.

Partially implements: blueprint multi-project-config

Change-Id: Ibfb38d07a36dfa7fe25381adc34cc1d3cbe7d1e1

commit_message:
Don't treat NoneType as a dict in rebuild

There is an assumption that the kwargs argument is a dict, though it may
be None. This is because cells isn't passing kwargs through in the
traditional way as a dict of extra arguments, but rather as a specific
argument. If it is None convert it to a dict before accessing it as a
dict.

Change-Id: I4a81179f564a8175e1d6a6ff0394c03ea17a756f
Closes-bug: #1477500
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/26/205026/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if kwargs is None: kwargs = {}

commit_message:
Fix auditd log permission bug

The tasks for handling auditd log permissions incorrectly set all
log files in /var/log/audit to 0400, which prevents auditd from
writing to the active log file. This prevents auditd from starting and
restarting.

The task now removes any permissions explicitly disallowed by
V-38498. Any files meeting/exceeding the STIG requirements will not be
modified.

Closes-bug: 1584942

Change-Id: I1bb2b91ae8a78b1f0304bd4ce0f9a774d65245bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/31/320131/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # On most systems, the active log file is 0600 and the older logs are 0400. # This task ensures that all logs meet or exceed the STIG requirement. mode: "u-x,g-wx,o-rwx"
deleted_lines: # Ubuntu 14.04 sets these to 0400 by default, so we will stick with that since # it exceeds the STIG's requirements. mode: 0400

commit_message:
deprecate usage of transport aliases

This change starts the deprecation process for the transport aliases.

The first step is deprecate this one cycle. To ensure deployer have
updated they configuration during Newton Then in Octacia we will deprecate
'aliases' kwargs of transportURL() and get_transport() for consuming
application.

Related-bug: #1424728

Change-Id: I314cefa5fb1803fa7e21e3e34300e5ced31bba89

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: retry on deadlock for create_resource()

This happens sometimes too:

oslo_db.exception.DBDeadlock: (psycopg2.extensions.TransactionRollbackError) deadlock detected
LINE 1: INSERT INTO resource (created_by_user_id, created_by_project...
                    ^'
DETAIL:  Process 11422 waits for RowExclusiveLock on relation 16412 of database 12066; blocked by process 11544.
Process 11544 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16442 of database 12066; blocked by process 11550.
Process 11550 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16412 of database 12066; blocked by process 11422.
HINT:  See server log for query details.

Change-Id: I3cbe55c0af7cd29838c7892300a8a3036c1e07f7
(cherry picked from commit 78503d99597e39216db86caa7d43c59dfb3e615c)

commit_message:
Improve l3 agent support

This patch improves the L3 agent support by:
 * Initialise router_scheduler in the l3 NAT mixin
 * Add l3_agent_scheduler to the supported extensions APIs
 * Use q-l3 service to run df-l3-agent as some checks in
   neutron/devstack are q-l3 specific

Change-Id: I19b4910049c7cee1ae04e3ca553190a720050a9d
Closes-Bug: 1574631
Closes-Bug: 1581946

This patch changes the state of the plan to be stored as a plan per

commit_message:
[WIP] Refactor plan and associated storage.

Previously the tripleo_common library stored the state of a plan
and all of its files as a plan per container with container and
object metadata.

This patch changes the state of the plan to be stored as a plan per
object in a single container to store all plans.  Template storage
has been modified to exist outside the plan.

There is still some work to do to get this where it needs to be:

- change template/file processing before sending to heatclient

- fix the unit tests / pep8

Change-Id: I181f6173f8ba45e91b8d6c1a013d5e7bc67e3aaf

subject: Fixes swift versioning
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-23 20:38:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/5acb1aa05354baefd7851548388b1b28d0f717ac', 'message': 'Fixes swift versioning

The current code in the repo doesn't support versioning properly.
When attempting to use this library in its current form, users are
presented with an error message similar to "412 Precondition not
met".

Each container must have it's own secondary container to store
previous versions of it's objects.  This patch adds the creation
of a secondary container unique to each plan and assigns it during
plan container creation.

commit_message:
Fixes swift versioning

The current code in the repo doesn't support versioning properly.
When attempting to use this library in its current form, users are
presented with an error message similar to "412 Precondition not
met".

Each container must have it's own secondary container to store
previous versions of it's objects.  This patch adds the creation
of a secondary container unique to each plan and assigns it during
plan container creation.

Change-Id: Ib782f20517497048cad2d5ea24fe00bc603a3e98

commit_message:
Organizes Swift exceptions into Swift Storage Backend

Deleting, updating or getting a plan swallows the exception if
it is from Swift and not a 404. This is also a leaky abstraction,
plan.py shouldn't know about Swift.

This patch removes any knowledge of Swift from plan.py and moves it
all into plan_storage.py.  This patch also improves the test coverage
of test for plan.py and plan_storage.py.

Change-Id: I1f85b55571f6dc119f33dd4dd7630d94c9c1bca1

commit_message:
Airflow event based migration strategy spec

This is one of the algorithm spec of Intel thermal POC

blueprint: uniform-airflow-migration-strategy

Change-Id: I5373645e88c59609af3c51825b681b411f37c3e8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs refs/changes/74/275474/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Uniform Airflow Migration Strategy ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/uniform-airflow-migration-strategy Airflow (Unit: CFM) is a cooling related telemetry which can be used to measure the cooling status of server. This spec proposes a new Watcher migration strategy based on the airflow of servers. This strategy makes decisions to migrate workloads to make the airflow uniform. Note: "server" in this document means "hypervisor". Problem description =================== In current Data Center infrastructure, the cooling air supply to servers can be different , depends on the workload and inlet temperature. When a server is overloaded or the supply air is too hot, the airflow can reach the threshold. In this case, we need to move the workload to other servers. Also, recirculation of airflow is another problem of the cooling efficiency. So the total airflow of servers should be less than the supply airflow of AC to avoid recirculation, that's why the airflow of server should be uniform. Use Cases ---------- As an administrator, I want to be able to trigger an audit that controls the airflow and perform workload load balancing. In order to: * Reduce the total power consumption spent on cooling. * Avoid airflow recirculation to improve the cooling efficiency. * Increase the lifespan of the data center because cooling effectiveness is a first order factor. Project Priority ----------------- Not relevant because Watcher is not in the big tent so far. Proposed change =============== Watcher already has its decision framework, so this strategy should be a new class which extend the base strategy class. * Set the threshold in 2 steps: hard coded first, then through the template. see: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/optimization-threshold * Create a new Python class to extend the "BaseStrategy" class. * Use the Ceilometer client to get Airflow, Inlet temperature, System Power metrics of hypervisors. * Use the Nova objects framework to get free CPU/Memory/Disk of hypervisors. * An algorithm to detect if the threshold of Airflow has been reached and if the threshold of Inlet temperature and System power also been reached, it will decide to move all workloads or just one only. It will filter the viable targets according to the free resource information of hypervisors from previous step. Alternatives ------------ No alternative Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ There used to be some performance issues regarding the query of metrics from the Ceilometer database. This is one of the reasons why it was rarely used in production environment. These issues may now be solved thanks to an abstraction layer which enables anybody to change the underlying metrics storage backend easily. There is also a performance issue when you query the Nova DB to get CPU usage metrics. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <edwin-zhai> Work Items ---------- 1. function to use Ceilometer client to get Airflow,Inlet temperature,System power of hypervisors. 2. function to filter servers by Nova basic metrics(free CPU/Memory/Disk). 3. Rewrite execute function to add the algorithm to detect the threshold and to choose the target hypervisors, generate action plans. Dependencies ============ * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Ceilometer/blueprints/APIv2 * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/api-v2-improvement * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/optimization-threshold * http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/telemetry-measurements.html * http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-novaclient/api.html Testing ======= Unit tests and functional test, will use a fake metrics set for running functional test. Documentation Impact ==================== A documentation explaining how to use this new optimization strategy. References ========== http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/servers/ipmi/ipmi-home.html History ======= None

added_lines: @mock.patch("%s.random.choice" % CTX, side_effect=lambda x: x[1]) def test_map_for_scenario_random_default(self, mock_choice): self.mixin.context["config"]["users"]["user_choice_method"] = None users_ = [] tenants = {} for i in ("0", "1"): tenants[i] = {"id": i, "name": i, "users": []} for j in ("a", "b", "c"): user = { "id": "%s_%s" % (i, j), "tenant_id": i, "credential": "credential", } users_.append(user) tenants[i]["users"].append(user) context = { "admin": mock.MagicMock(), "users": users_, "tenants": tenants, "some_random_key": { "nested": mock.MagicMock(), "one_more": 10 }, "config": { }, } chosen_tenant = context["tenants"][context["users"][1]["tenant_id"]] expected_context = { "admin": context["admin"], "user": context["users"][1], "tenant": chosen_tenant, "some_random_key": context["some_random_key"], "config": context["config"] } self.assertEqual( expected_context, self.mixin.map_for_scenario(context) )

commit_message:
Add yaql function

Add function that can evaluate yaql expression on a given
data. YAQL (Yet Another Query Language) is an embeddable
and extensible query language, that allows performing complex
queries against arbitrary objects.
https://github.com/openstack/yaql
small example in yaql_example.yaml

implements-bp yaql-function
Co-Authored-By: Oleksii Chuprykov <ochuprykov@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I63885f5754cb19325ff199920ebed5db9b278786

commit_message:
Set the time point polling starts as timestamp of samples

Many of the pollsters define the timestamp individually for each
generated sample, which should really be timestamping based on when
the data was polled and not when each sample is generated. We need to
set the timestamp of the polled data to the timestamp when the polling
starts for unity.

This commit set the time point when the polling starts as the timestamp
of samples, and make 'timestamp' argument of Sample.__init__ method
optional.

The timestamping in polling agents will be dropped in following patches.

Change-Id: I3be3f7fb8300e8853ebd35986cdf159422aa247a
Partial-Bug: #1491509
Partially-Implements: blueprint unify-timestamp-of-polled-data

added_lines: pollster.get_current_timestamp = \ mock.Mock(return_value=self.timestamp) self.assertEqual(set([self.timestamp]), set([s.timestamp for s in samples])) pollster.get_current_timestamp = \ mock.Mock(return_value=self.timestamp) self.assertEqual(set([self.timestamp]), set([s.timestamp for s in samples]))

Add hardware properties methods to management interface

This patch adds methods for hardware properties management to
base drivers management interface.

Implements: blueprint ironic-management-properties

commit_message:
Close fd created by mkstemp

In PuppetApplyHost archivator file descriptor returned by mkstemp is ignored
and thus remains open after function finishes.

Change-Id: Ief11db89680082bec10da161277fdf1b2ff436a3
Closes-bug: 1572918
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/50/318550/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os fd, tmp_file_name = tempfile.mkstemp( os.close(fd)

commit_message:
Allow passing list of dicts for create-vms-conf command.

Previous implementation of command "fuel2 node create-vms-conf"
didn't allow using list of dicts for --conf parameter. It required
to use multiple arguments like:
    --conf '{"id": 1}' '{"id": 2}'
which is non obvious for user and inconsistent with UI (in UI
user sees list of dicts).
This patch introduces new possibility to pass parameters
as json list:
    --conf '[{"id": 1}, {"id": 2}]'

Change-Id: I50e961c1afce91fd1c43d1fdcf6436a08a20c2be
Related-Bug: #1582136
Closes-Bug: #1582120

commit_message:
Remove deprecated driver_periodic_task

This decorator was deprecated February 24, 2016; we're past the cycle
boundary and 3 month requirements. Remove it.

Change-Id: I9c08e7111aac9b8baf6878e508db1fbfa0ec72cb

commit_message:
[WIP] Add notification event listener service

A new notification event listener service is added to Mistral. It
listens for specific events from other OpenStack services on the AMQP
bus and calls the appropriate workflows to perform actions as a
result of receiving the events. The mapping of notification events to
workflow name is provided in a JSON file.

1. A change was made to mistral/api/app.py to start the notification
event listener service.

2. The new notification event service was added along with a messaging
support module which calls oslo messaging functions.

3. A sample JSON mapping file,
notification_event_type_to_wf_map.json, is provided which maps some
OpenStack events to workflow names. The AMQP event topic and exchange
are also specified in the JSON mapping file, giving it the capability
to support all OpenStack notification events.

4. The workflows called after an event is received must support two
input arguments. The first is the event type value, and the second is
a dictionary containing the notification event message payload
received. The workflow can take the appropriate action based on the
event type and the event payload.

This is a work in progress.

Change-Id: Ib9d69ded0d4bb9a6cc89c0dcb8db3072c30c3189
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/13/248813/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # # Copyright 2015 - IBM Corp. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import Queue import threading from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_messaging import transport from mistral import context as auth_ctx from mistral.engine import default_engine as def_eng from mistral.engine import rpc from mistral.services import messaging # AMQP constants DEFAULT_AMQP_TOPIC = 'notifications' # Event queue event constants EVENT_TYPE = 'type' EVENT_CONTEXT = 'context' EVENT_MESSAGE = 'message' EVENT_PAYLOAD = 'payload' REAL_EVENT_TYPE = 'real_type' REAL_EVENT_CONTEXT = 'ctxt' NOTIFICATION_EVENT_TYPE = 'notification_event_type' # Event queue event types NOTIFICATION_EVENT = 'notification_event' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CONF = cfg.CONF class MistralNotificationsHandler(object): """Process certain notification events from the OpenStack cloud. When an instance create event occurs, start a workflow to begin the expiration of that instance. """ def __init__(self): """Create a MistralNotificationsHandler.""" # The queue used for processing notification events self.event_queue = Queue.Queue() # The event_type to workflow name map self.event_type_to_wf_name = {} # The mapping dict self.notifications_map = {} # RPC engine client and engine self.engine_client = None self.engine = None def start(self): """Starts the Mistral notifications handler.""" # Dump the CONF CONF.log_opt_values(LOG, logging.INFO) # Get the Mistral engine to use for starting workflows trans = transport.get_transport(CONF) self.engine_client = rpc.EngineClient(trans) self.engine = def_eng.DefaultEngine(self.engine_client) # Get the notification event type to workflow name map which includes # the AMQP exchanges and topic names. try: self.notifications_map = messaging.get_mapping() except Exception as e: LOG.error("An error occurred getting the notification event type" " to workflow name map: %s" % e) LOG.error("Notifications from other OpenStack services will not" " be processed.") # Start up the event handler and notification task self._start_event_handler() self._start_event_notification_task() def _start_event_notification_task(self): """Kick off the event notification task.""" LOG.debug('Starting event notification task...') # Start a thread here to process the event queue t = threading.Thread(target=self._process_event_queue) t.daemon = True t.start() def _start_event_handler(self): """Start the event handler. Start the notification event handler if it's not already running. """ LOG.debug("Enter _start_event_handler method") # Start listeners for each of the AMQP exchanges found in the mapping # JSON file. Each will have an optional AMQP topic and a list of events # to process. if self.notifications_map: exchanges = self.notifications_map['exchanges'] \ if 'exchanges' in self.notifications_map.keys() else None if exchanges: for exchange_name in exchanges.keys(): exchange = exchanges[exchange_name] topic = exchange['topic'] \ if 'topic' in exchange else DEFAULT_AMQP_TOPIC events = exchange['events'] \ if 'events' in exchange else None if events is not None: event_names = events.keys() # Save the event_type to workflow name map for event in events.keys(): self.event_type_to_wf_name[event] = events[event] endpoint = messaging.NotificationEndpoint(log=LOG) # All notification events will be processed by a single # method endpoint.register_handler(event_names, self._process_notification) endpoints = [ endpoint, ] LOG.debug("Starting to listen to AMQP exchange '%s'," " and topic '%s' for events '%s'... " % (exchange_name, topic, str(event_names))) messaging.start_listener(CONF, exchange_name, topic, endpoints) else: LOG.error("No events were found in the notifications" " mapping JSON.") else: LOG.error("No exchanges were found in the notifications" " mapping JSON.") else: LOG.error("Notifications event type to workflow name mapping" " cannot be determined.") LOG.debug("Exit _start_event_handler method") def _process_notification(self, context=None, ctxt=None, event_type=None, payload=None): """Process notifications. Place the incoming notification event on the event queue for processing. :param: context The security context :param: ctxt message context :param: event_type message event type :param: payload The AMQP message sent from OpenStack (dictionary) """ event = {EVENT_TYPE: NOTIFICATION_EVENT, EVENT_CONTEXT: context, REAL_EVENT_CONTEXT: ctxt, REAL_EVENT_TYPE: event_type, EVENT_PAYLOAD: payload} LOG.debug('Adding notification event to event queue: %s', str(event)) self.event_queue.put(event) def _process_event_queue(self): """Process the event queue. The event queue events are a dict made up of the event type, the context, and the message payload. """ while True: LOG.debug("Waiting for events on the event queue...") event = self.event_queue.get() try: context = event.get(EVENT_CONTEXT) event_type = event.get(EVENT_TYPE) ctxt = event.get(REAL_EVENT_CONTEXT) real_type = event.get(REAL_EVENT_TYPE) payload = event.get(EVENT_PAYLOAD) if event_type == NOTIFICATION_EVENT: LOG.debug(('Processing a notification event on ' 'the event queue: %s'), str(event)) self._handle_notifications(context=context, ctxt=ctxt, event_type=real_type, payload=payload, ) else: LOG.debug(('An unknown event type was found on the event' ' queue: %s'), str(event)) except Exception as e: LOG.exception(('An error occurred processing the notification' ' event from the event queue: %s'), e) finally: self.event_queue.task_done() def _handle_notifications(self, context=None, ctxt=None, event_type=None, payload=None): """Handle notification events received from OS. :param: context The security context :param: ctxt message context :param: event_type message event type :param: payload The AMQP message sent from OpenStack (dictionary) """ LOG.debug("A '%s' notification event was received." % event_type) if event_type in self.event_type_to_wf_name.keys(): self._process_notification_event(event_type, context, ctxt, payload) else: LOG.debug("Did not process unknown event: type:'%s', payload:'%s'" % (event_type, str(payload))) def _process_notification_event(self, event_type, context, ctxt, payload): """Process a notification event. Start the workflow for a particular event_type as defined in the mapping JSON file. """ LOG.debug("Processing notification event '%s'..." % event_type) try: # TODO(mowrer): Investigate context. Try to use the message # context. The security context is None. LOG.debug("Notification event:") LOG.debug("\tEvent type: %s" % event_type) LOG.debug("\tSecurity context: %s" % context) LOG.debug("\tMessage context: %s" % ctxt) LOG.debug("\tEvent payload: %s" % str(payload)) # Get the workflow name based on the notification event type if event_type in self.event_type_to_wf_name.keys(): wf_name = self.event_type_to_wf_name[event_type] # Build workflow input which consists of the notification event # type and the event payload wf_input = {NOTIFICATION_EVENT_TYPE: event_type, 'payload': payload} # Create MistralContext to run the workflow under. If the event # did not contain a context, try to run the workflow with the # context defined in CONF. if ctxt: # Apply mapping of user_id and project_id for different # context types user = ctxt['user_id'] \ if 'user_id' in ctxt.keys() else None if user is None: user = ctxt['user'] if 'user' in ctxt.keys() else None project = ctxt['project_id'] \ if 'project_id' in ctxt.keys() else None if project is None: project = ctxt['tenant'] \ if 'tenant' in ctxt.keys() else None # If the context is not found, attempt to run the workflow # as an admin. mctxt = auth_ctx.MistralContext( user_id=user, project_id=project, auth_token=ctxt['auth_token'] if 'auth_token' in ctxt.keys() else None, is_admin=ctxt['is_admin'] if 'is_admin' in ctxt.keys() else True, is_trust_scoped=False ) else: mctxt = auth_ctx.context_from_config() LOG.debug("\tMistral context: %s" % str(mctxt)) # Set the context in thread local before starting the workflow auth_ctx.set_ctx(mctxt) # Start the workflow LOG.info("Starting workflow '%s'..." % wf_name) LOG.debug("Workflow input: %s" % wf_input) self.engine.start_workflow(wf_name, wf_input) else: LOG.error( "An unexpected error occurred. The workflow name for" " event '%s' could not be determined." % event_type) except Exception as e: LOG.exception("An error occurred processing the notification" " event '%s': %s" % (event_type, e)) finally: auth_ctx.set_ctx(None) # Mistral Notification Handlers. Make it possible to have more than one in the # future if desired which can be access here but name. _notification_handlers = {} DEFAULT_NOTIFICATIONS_HANDLER_NAME = 'default' def setup(name=DEFAULT_NOTIFICATIONS_HANDLER_NAME): """Setup the notifications handler. Create the MistralNotificationsHandler if it doesn't exit, and start it. The notification handler name is optional. """ if name not in _notification_handlers.keys(): LOG.info("Starting the '%s' Mistral Notifications Handler." % name) _notification_handlers[name] = MistralNotificationsHandler() _notification_handlers[name].start() else: LOG.info("The '%s' Mistral Notifications Handler is already running." % name) def start_notifications_handler(name=DEFAULT_NOTIFICATIONS_HANDLER_NAME): """Start the notifications handler. Start the specified Mistral notification handler, if needed, and return it. :param name: The optional name of the notification handler. :return: The notification handler. """ setup(name) return _notification_handlers[name]

commit_message:
Add other-requirements.txt for bindep

Bindep is a binary automation tool used in openstack-infra.  With it,
projects can better control the default packages installed into the
OS. Because we are using puppet, we actually don't want any packages
installed by default as to better test our manifests.

Change-Id: I0ef8975cd249cbe35b64732f5b8696c6cb9288b0
Co-Authored-By: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-barbican refs/changes/80/318780/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix update_password tests

The current implementation uses object shallow copy to
get new credentials and clients to restore the password
after update, which is fragile and a bit complicated.

Using one client is enough. To restore the password
we clear auth to ensure a new token is requested, set the
new password temporarily, restore the password and finally
reset auth again.

Change-Id: I41f442ee89b1bd37dacb02b5ca276abd85981295
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/94/319394/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _restore_password(client, user_id, old_pass, new_pass): # Reset auth to get a new token with the new password client.auth_provider.clear_auth() client.auth_provider.credentials.password = new_pass client.update_user_own_password(user_id, password=old_pass, original_password=new_pass) # Reset auth again to verify the password restore does work time.sleep(1) # Clear auth restores the original credentials and deletes # cached auth data client.auth_provider.clear_auth() client.auth_provider.set_auth() old_pass = self.creds.credentials.password new_pass = data_utils.rand_password() user_id = self.creds.credentials.user_id self.addCleanup(_restore_password, self.non_admin_users_client, user_id, old_pass=old_pass, new_pass=new_pass)
deleted_lines: import copyfrom tempest import manager self.new_creds = copy.copy(self.creds.credentials) self.new_creds.password = data_utils.rand_password() # we need new non-admin Identity Client with new credentials, since # current non_admin_client token will be revoked after updating # password self.non_admin_users_client_for_cleanup = copy.copy( self.non_admin_users_client) self.non_admin_users_client_for_cleanup.auth_provider = ( manager.get_auth_provider(self.new_creds)) user_id = self.creds.credentials.user_id old_pass = self.creds.credentials.password new_pass = self.new_creds.password self.addCleanup( self.non_admin_users_client_for_cleanup.update_user_own_password, user_id, original_password=new_pass, password=old_pass)

commit_message:
Correct the 'Admin Guide' title name

Since Mitaka reorganised the Admin User Guide content together with the
Cloud Admin Guide content to create a new Administrator Guide. So the
title should be "OpenStack Administrator Guide". Refer to
'http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-manuals/mitaka.html#user-guides'

Change-Id: Ic0b8e8defe5942dd1e6ca50a7af13708c5653166
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/25/320425/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: or the `OpenStack Administrator Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/networking_adv-features.html#provider-networks>`__.or the `OpenStack Administrator Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/networking_adv-features.html#provider-networks>`__.

Convert to strutils.bool_from_string

We had some remaining users of _get_bool that really deserved to be converted
to oslo's strutils.bool_from_string.

Change-Id: I4465975bbc31988b8e1c565a51b64c2613d048dc

commit_message:
Fix 'reset_on_ready_ubuntu_bootstrap' test

Update the approach to waiting nodes to appear online after
env reset. Wait not only for 'online' nailgun status of nodes,
but also ensure that nodes are accessible.

Change-Id: Iae7fde7646d1edf2a3353c664def134589cc41e0
Closes-Bug: #1572470
(cherry picked from commit af1955cffc6081a8221143d4090950910ac99c9e)

added_lines: from devops.helpers.helpers import tcp_ping nailgun_node = self.fuel_web.get_nailgun_node_by_devops_node(node) wait(lambda: tcp_ping(nailgun_node['ip'], 22), timeout=300, timeout_msg=("Node {0} is still unreachable after {1} " "seconds".format(nailgun_node['name'], 300))) checkers.verify_bootstrap_on_node( nailgun_node['ip'], os_type="ubuntu")

commit_message:
Unhealthy ceph don't break upgrade

Bad health ceph status shouldn't stop node upgrade.
The reason is fuel overestimates ceph default value for pool
placement groups number.

Change-Id: Iff301ffeedd26a6f532dbbd480a6395cd774181a
Related-Bug: 1464656

commit_message:
Factor out Install Guide for Debian with debconf

To simplify the build tool chain,
factor out Install Guide for Debian with debconf.
Continueously, keep Install Guide for Debian without debconf
in the doc/install-guide directory. Also, use the contents
at doc/install-guide as possible for consistency.

On the following patches, clean up doc/install-guide sources
to cleanup the contents and build tool chains.

Change-Id: I8df6b3b382137d08d60f85bc41bcd98ac1f4eb47

commit_message:
Remove nested transaction from ipam driver

Using nested transaction in reference ipam driver causes rewriting
original exception due failure to restore to safepoint in case of
DeadLock.

DBDeadlock exception gets replaced with DBAPIError. It prevents db_retry
wrapper from working correctly.

This patch removed nested transaction block from reference ipam driver.

Change-Id: Ib710e87b0132aae3cd3afd12c5448961f1a3b25c
Partial-Bug: #1571666

commit_message:
Get rid of check_wrong_config test

There was a list of hardcoded services that allow us to use
service-reconfiguration. Now there is no strict limitation
on services that could be configured with this feature.
This mean that test check_wrong_config is deprecated and should be
deleted

Change-Id: I729bf0235eea525cc0464346ca791ca7733e5de9
Related-Bug: #1580522
Closes-bug: #1584693

commit_message:
Fix getting previous state for deployment

Now we get last success transaction not only for every task but for
every node in the cluster. The previous version of state collecting
function may lead to false-positive choice of previous deployment
transaction and issues with smart YAQL-based redeployment.

Change-Id: If9e22924acb465487a2fa97534fe50f03a1590a1
Closes-Bug: #1581015
Closes-Bug: #1582269
(cherry picked from commit 5ba7416156786e6d409c6f3a969441b55c2ea2bb)

subject: Do not attempt to re-install docker, regardless of its running status
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 23:43:03.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/d32f09ffb653da1651541162debaaa0d3887bce4', 'message': 'Do not attempt to re-install docker, regardless of its running status

Commit c96032ecc11b44b53f60c6240ffb05439fe57a91 changed the devstack
plugin to avoid reinstalling docker if the service was running.
However, there are a few meaningful cases where the service is not
running but the package is however installed and the user does not
want devstack to reinstall it.

This patch uses the distro package manager to find whether
docker-engine is insstalled already, rather than systemd or init.d.
The docker installation script will take care of cases where docker
was manually installed from binaries.

Change-Id: I6f66fdd3c35739486a6453b484eab81dfb4a9545
'}]
commit_message:
Do not attempt to re-install docker, regardless of its running status

Commit c96032ecc11b44b53f60c6240ffb05439fe57a91 changed the devstack
plugin to avoid reinstalling docker if the service was running.
However, there are a few meaningful cases where the service is not
running but the package is however installed and the user does not
want devstack to reinstall it.

This patch uses the distro package manager to find whether
docker-engine is insstalled already, rather than systemd or init.d.
The docker installation script will take care of cases where docker
was manually installed from binaries.

Change-Id: I6f66fdd3c35739486a6453b484eab81dfb4a9545

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-18 20:24:49.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/services/identity/v3/json/projects_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/43cee11d9b7a5b99f3769e34bb64a5101fd635e4', 'message': 'Modify projects_client to receive more attributes

commit_message:
Modify projects_client to receive more attributes

Starting in Keystone v3.4 the parent_id attribute was introduced for
projects as a way for creating projects within a hierarchy. Also in
v3.6 the is_domain attribute was added. The pojects_client that is
part of the identity v3 clients implemented in Tempest was missing
these attributes. Instead of adding the individual prameters to the
client, this commits allow users to pass as many parameters as they
want to the create_project and update_project methods through the
kwargs, so whenever new attributes are added to Keystone they can
be used in the identity v3 client in Tempest.

Change-Id: I171fa21113298c1e01ddc98ebd1791c46223d69b

commit_message:
Use 'Delete Instance' rather than 'Terminate' in legacy topology

In Mitaka cycle, we replaced 'Terminate Instance' with 'Delete Instance'.
The legacy network topology view restored recently introduced
'Terminate Instance'. This commit fixes it.

Change-Id: I26138b792b71916dddea47b1146668bea29274dc

commit_message:
Use gzip for snapshots

On the 15G snapshot data gz is 10 times faster than xz while compression
rate is just 36% against 50% with gzip.
For the pattern "create once - download once" this looks like a
reasonable solution.

Change-Id: I5d2ce3681ec6555a8994bb39def907006be8b79f
Closes-Bug: #1546023
(cherry picked from commit 5afd0ac1e1e4a354f74a8356a64c1a5712fc4dbf)

commit_message:
Out of space detection during compression

Since compression command is actually a pipeline
we cannot use return code to detect out of space condition
so, the only way is to parse stderr

Change-Id: I2a95333bcabb73d0716d9790e14851cfefd47478
Partial-Bug: #1543491
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shotgun refs/changes/77/315477/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errnodef is_out_of_space(code, errdata): if code: # Since compression command is actually a pipeline # we cannot use return code to detect out of space condition # so, the only way is to parse stderr return errdata.lower().find('no space left'.encode()) >= 0 env['LANG'] = 'C' # We need non localized output code, _, errdata = execute( "tar chJf {0}.tar.xz -C {1} {2}{3}" "".format(target, os.path.dirname(target), os.path.basename(target), "".join(' --exclude={}'.format(e) for e in exclude)), env=env) if is_out_of_space(code, errdata): raise IOError(errno.ENOSPC)
deleted_lines: execute("tar chJvf {0}.tar.xz -C {1} {2}{3}" "".format(target, os.path.dirname(target), os.path.basename(target), "".join(' --exclude {}'.format(e) for e in exclude)), env=env)

commit_message:
Creates instances_path in driver init_host method

In case the configured instance path does not exist, we create it
when the host is initialized.

Change-Id: Iac506597aac4af670725c7d1ed139b2459bc3887
Closes-Bug: #1572948

commit_message:
FC volume driver: log the volume mappings

In some cases, the FC attached disk path cannot be retrieved.

To make debugging easier, we can log the mappings that we found for
that specific FC volume.

Change-Id: I08119a427c2f4a5ed5b782f7c90e66045cbb3fe9

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: add retry on deadlock for delete_resource()

Deleting a resource can trigger a deadlock using PostgreSQL.

 oslo_db.exception.DBDeadlock: (psycopg2.extensions.TransactionRollbackError) deadlock detected
 DETAIL:  Process 91956 waits for RowExclusiveLock on relation 21454 of database 12641; blocked by process 91968.
 Process 91968 waits for ShareRowExclusiveLock on relation 21416 of database 12641; blocked by process 91956.
 HINT:  See server log for query details.
  [SQL: 'DELETE FROM resource WHERE resource.id = %(id_1)s'] [parameters: {'id_1': UUID('4b935d09-6aa6-4403-8f8c-a76628bfad60')}]

Change-Id: Ife5c3ae5fdf921f27a6ca964d82e99a4ae45aa0a

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: retry on deadlock for create_resource()

This happens sometimes too:

oslo_db.exception.DBDeadlock: (psycopg2.extensions.TransactionRollbackError) deadlock detected
LINE 1: INSERT INTO resource (created_by_user_id, created_by_project...
                    ^'
DETAIL:  Process 11422 waits for RowExclusiveLock on relation 16412 of database 12066; blocked by process 11544.
Process 11544 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16442 of database 12066; blocked by process 11550.
Process 11550 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16412 of database 12066; blocked by process 11422.
HINT:  See server log for query details.

Change-Id: I3cbe55c0af7cd29838c7892300a8a3036c1e07f7

commit_message:
Wait for all interfaces to get IP addresses during inspection with extras

The DIB build of IPA runs DHCP in parallel with IPA service. This can cause
some interfaces to get their IP addresses only after inspection.
As IP addresses can be an important part of the extra inspection data,
pass the kernel flag to wait for all interfaces if inspection_extras=True.

Change-Id: I8995d900c19a44cb907d47b971a13bdacd233d79
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/40/315440/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if CONF.inspection_extras: inspection_kernel_args.append('ipa-inspection-dhcp-all-interfaces=1')

commit_message:
Add method for retrieving local share paths

This will be used by Nova in order to properly handle volumes
residing on local shares.

Partial-Bug: 1580122
Change-Id: I8e4426b3b1044d24563adf7826ab9f141c2495b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-win refs/changes/90/314490/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_smb_share_path(self, share_name): shares = self._smb_conn.Msft_SmbShare(Name=share_name) share_path = shares[0].Path if shares else None if not shares: LOG.debug("Could not find any local share named %s.", share_name) return share_path

commit_message:
Hyper-V: properly handle loopback shares

At the moment, the Hyper-V driver uses the UNC path of images
stored on SMB shares, regardless if the share is remote or not.
According to the MS docs, this is not supported for SOFS SMB shares.

This is troublesome for the Hyper-C scenario, as Hyper-V will attempt
to modify the image ACLs, making them unusable.

The fix consists in checking if the share is local, and use the
local path in that case.

Depends-On: I8e4426b3b1044d24563adf7826ab9f141c2495b8
Closes-Bug: #1580122

Change-Id: Ib736b39f3bfa58b2737647de23f741ffcf85180b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/compute-hyperv refs/changes/13/314513/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return connection_info[ 'data']['export'].replace('/', '\\').rstrip('\\') # In case of loopback shares, we use the local share path. local_share_path = self._get_loopback_share_path(export) if local_share_path: export = local_share_path def _get_loopback_share_path(self, share_address): # In case of loopback shares, we use the local share path. local_share_path = self._smbutils.get_smb_share_path( share_address) try: if local_share_path and self._pathutils.check_dirs_shared_storage( local_share_path, share_address): return local_share_path except Exception: err_msg = _LE("Got exception while verifying if share %s " "is local, thus it will not be handled as a " "loopback share") LOG.exception(err_msg, share_address)

commit_message:
Cleanup hieradata to reduce Puppet warnings

Some puppet were deprecated, some of them removed.
This patch reduce the number of warnings to a few, and the rest of
warnings are bugs that are in progress by Puppet OpenStack team.

This patch is mostly some cleanup so we don't have useless warnings in
Puppet catalog.

Change-Id: I4d91912fa22557debdb53f6d53c9906857579d3b

commit_message:
Change incorrect murano-agent bin file location

During cloud-init related improvements murano-agent location was
specified for the pip-style installation. This leads to unability
to deploy the apps on the images with pre-installed murano-agent
without network. This commit create a symlink to the pre-installed agent
in place where pip usually installs packages.

Change-Id: I8d90d33dc0a1c36ac4524f8f3b82223c23829126
Closes-Bug: #1570962

commit_message:
Remove the orchestration property from tripleoclient class

Use the OSC-compatible orchestration client instead of the home-grown
one. This reduces duplicate code, and relies on more thoroughly tested
code elsewhere.

Change-Id: Ib77d20086f86a260197c6f289fd9c270b766544c
Depends-On: I7aa0fd7c152ee91b6e2b956f7e594f8c8aacafa7

commit_message:
Downcase all hostnames for MySQL user/db creation

Mysql puppet providers apply downcase method for hostnames, that
lead us to errors when we use hostnames with upper-case letters.

Change-Id: Ic21bf428f661337fdf95d7c4416a1428a974f0f1
Closes-Bug: 1584247
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/20/320320/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Allow a user to access the database for the service # # == Namevar # String with the form dbname_host. The host part of the string is the host # to allow # # == Parameters # [*user*] # username to allow # # [*password_hash*] # user password hash # # [*database*] # the database name # # [*privileges*] # the privileges to grant to this user # define openstacklib::db::mysql::host_access ( $user, $password_hash, $database, $privileges, ) { validate_re($title, '_', 'Title must be $dbname_$host') $host = downcase(inline_template('<%= @title.split("_").last %>')) mysql_user { "${user}@${host}": password_hash => $password_hash, require => Mysql_database[$database], } mysql_grant { "${user}@${host}/${database}.*": privileges => $privileges, table => "${database}.*", require => Mysql_user["${user}@${host}"], user => "${user}@${host}", } }

commit_message:
Use region from config in functional tests

We seem to be using hardcoded region in some inline
templates of fucntional tests. They would fail if
the region name is different. This changes to use
it from the config.

Change-Id: Iafd1251545e00c6cba292b042352b1ef34da81e0
Closes-Bug: #1560585

subject: 'GetPackageUI' API can now be called even if Glare is used
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-24 11:35:09.000000000', 'files': ['murano/context.py', 'murano/api/middleware/context.py', 'murano/api/v1/catalog.py', 'releasenotes/notes/enable-hot-for-glare-8026f2dccad1732e.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/730bcf122504df9cf4462b7d44c5a3dd994fb96b', 'message': ''GetPackageUI' API can now be called even if Glare is used

Since Glare support was introduced the 'catalog/packages' part of
Murano API (/v1/catalog/packages) became obsolete and was intended to
be used for "legacy" (i.e. non-glare-based) package storage. The
murano client was supposed to directly call glare to retrieve the
packages.

However, the "GetPackageUI" call (GET
/v1/catalog/packages/%pkg_id%/ui) is different: not all the packages
bundle the UI definitions, some require Murano to generate them based
on the contents of the package. This is true for HOT-based packages
and others, plugin-based ones. In future this will be true for 100% of
the packages when the dynamic ui and object model generation is added.

Because of this that API should be callable even if Glare is
configured as a package storage backend. It should fetch the artifact
from glare, unpack it and use whatever plugin-specific logic required
to generate the UI definitions for this particular package.

This patch introduces appropriate change while maintaining the
backwards compatibility: in the legacy mode (i.e. when murano's DB
acts as package storage) the UI is read directly from an appropriate
DB table without fetching the whole package.

This fixes the issue when the HOT-based packages could not be
deplpoyed properly with murano-dashboard, but the murano-client has to
be updated as well to properly call the modified API even if Glare is
enabled.

Change-Id: Id9327e4015e1c0a1553c0b1a0151a94ee4da2928
Partial-bug: #1565805
(cherry picked from commit c81fc4b79a5054949b253a375b660c7de33f852f)
'}]
commit_message:
'GetPackageUI' API can now be called even if Glare is used

Since Glare support was introduced the 'catalog/packages' part of
Murano API (/v1/catalog/packages) became obsolete and was intended to
be used for "legacy" (i.e. non-glare-based) package storage. The
murano client was supposed to directly call glare to retrieve the
packages.

However, the "GetPackageUI" call (GET
/v1/catalog/packages/%pkg_id%/ui) is different: not all the packages
bundle the UI definitions, some require Murano to generate them based
on the contents of the package. This is true for HOT-based packages
and others, plugin-based ones. In future this will be true for 100% of
the packages when the dynamic ui and object model generation is added.

Because of this that API should be callable even if Glare is
configured as a package storage backend. It should fetch the artifact
from glare, unpack it and use whatever plugin-specific logic required
to generate the UI definitions for this particular package.

This patch introduces appropriate change while maintaining the
backwards compatibility: in the legacy mode (i.e. when murano's DB
acts as package storage) the UI is read directly from an appropriate
DB table without fetching the whole package.

This fixes the issue when the HOT-based packages could not be
deplpoyed properly with murano-dashboard, but the murano-client has to
be updated as well to properly call the modified API even if Glare is
enabled.

Change-Id: Id9327e4015e1c0a1553c0b1a0151a94ee4da2928
Partial-bug: #1565805
(cherry picked from commit c81fc4b79a5054949b253a375b660c7de33f852f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/72/320372/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - Fixed a bug when the UI dialog was not displayed in Murano Dashboard for applications which don't have UI definitions bundled in the package but generate them based on the package contents instead. This usually affected HOT-based packages and other non-muranopl-based applications.

commit_message:
'GetPackageUI' API can now be called even if Glare is used

Since Glare support was introduced the 'catalog/packages' part of
Murano API (/v1/catalog/packages) became obsolete and was intended to
be used for "legacy" (i.e. non-glare-based) package storage. The
murano client was supposed to directly call glare to retrieve the
packages.

However, the "GetPackageUI" call (GET
/v1/catalog/packages/%pkg_id%/ui) is different: not all the packages
bundle the UI definitions, some require Murano to generate them based
on the contents of the package. This is true for HOT-based packages
and others, plugin-based ones. In future this will be true for 100% of
the packages when the dynamic ui and object model generation is added.

Because of this that API should be callable even if Glare is
configured as a package storage backend. It should fetch the artifact
from glare, unpack it and use whatever plugin-specific logic required
to generate the UI definitions for this particular package.

This patch introduces appropriate change while maintaining the
backwards compatibility: in the legacy mode (i.e. when murano's DB
acts as package storage) the UI is read directly from an appropriate
DB table without fetching the whole package.

This fixes the issue when the HOT-based packages could not be
deplpoyed properly with murano-dashboard, but the murano-client has to
be updated as well to properly call the modified API even if Glare is
enabled.

Change-Id: Id9327e4015e1c0a1553c0b1a0151a94ee4da2928
Partial-bug: #1565805

commit_message:
This patch implements port security app

Port security application will install or uninstall flows
that let only the packets with valid ip and mac pass.

depend on: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/274093/

Change-Id: Ide4b159f99f8d92bc4aa965e932390275866841b
Implements: blueprint mac-spoofing-protection

commit_message:
Support GLARE installation in devstack Murano plugin

- Configure Murano to use Glance Artifacts Repository service
- Configure Murano-dashboard to support the same service

Change-Id: Iac4f1ff03ebf9908deb0959db96fac92316e67cd
targets: blueprint murano-glare-devstack-testing

commit_message:
Block delete_(network|subnet) transactioned calls

These functions assume that they won't be called inside of a
transaction for two reasons. The first is an infinite loop that
will only terminate if it can actually retrieve the latest
information from the database. The second is that ML2's post-commit
operations are expected to occur after data was actually committed
so mechanism drivers that do DB lookups using a different session
may break.

This adds an explicit guard that prevents these two functions from
being called within an active DB session. The rest of the ML2
functions should eventually be converted to this style as well
(see the partial bug).

Conflicts:
	doc/source/devref/service_extensions.rst
	neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py

Related-Bug: #1551958
Partial-Bug: #1540844
Change-Id: I5c00b186585369ef6c8e2b9cb5a43b8bba0e5a7c
(cherry picked from commit afe1a834000d33900b8646d308fa26fa807a2ca0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/22/314022/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functools def transaction_guard(f): """Ensures that the context passed in is not in a transaction. Many of ML2's methods modifying resources have assumptions that they will not be called inside of a transaction because they perform operations that expect all data to be committed to the database (all postcommit calls). Calling them in a transaction can lead to consistency errors on failures since the ML2 drivers will not be notified of a DB rollback. If you receive this error, you must alter your code to handle the fact that ML2 calls have side effects so using transactions to undo on failures is not possible. """ @functools.wraps(f) def inner(self, context, *args, **kwargs): if context.session.is_active: raise RuntimeError(_("Method cannot be called within a " "transaction.")) return f(self, context, *args, **kwargs) return inner @transaction_guard @transaction_guard
