commit_message:
Add lbaas v2 scenario test

Make use of the new lbaas v2 resources.
This is an experimental gate job.

Will use the lbaas v2 namespace-haproxy driver instead of octavia.  Octavia
requires nested vms which is very slow and causes timeouts in devstack gates.

Change-Id: I7ea6e50a1da46622bdddcfccaf82203f473bfacc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/08/237608/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2015-04-30 description: | Template which tests Neutron load balancing requests to members of Heat AutoScalingGroup. This uses LBaas V2. Instances must be running some webserver on a given app_port producing HTTP response that is different between servers but stable over time for given server. parameters: flavor: type: string image: type: string net: type: string subnet: type: string public_net: type: string app_port: type: number default: 8080 lb_port: type: number default: 80 timeout: type: number default: 600 resources: sec_group: type: OS::Neutron::SecurityGroup properties: rules: - remote_ip_prefix: 0.0.0.0/0 protocol: tcp port_range_min: { get_param: app_port } port_range_max: { get_param: app_port } asg: type: OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup properties: desired_capacity: 1 max_size: 2 min_size: 1 resource: type: OS::Test::NeutronAppServer properties: image: { get_param: image } flavor: { get_param: flavor } net: { get_param: net} sec_group: { get_resource: sec_group } app_port: { get_param: app_port } pool_id: { get_resource: pool } subnet: { get_param: subnet } timeout: { get_param: timeout } scale_up: type: OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy properties: adjustment_type: change_in_capacity auto_scaling_group_id: { get_resource: asg } scaling_adjustment: 1 scale_down: type: OS::Heat::ScalingPolicy properties: adjustment_type: change_in_capacity auto_scaling_group_id: { get_resource: asg } scaling_adjustment: -1 health_monitor: type: OS::Neutron::HealthMonitorV2 properties: delay: 3 type: HTTP timeout: 3 max_retries: 3 pool: { get_resource: pool } pool: type: OS::Neutron::PoolV2 properties: lb_algorithm: ROUND_ROBIN protocol: HTTP listener: { get_resource: listener } listener: type: OS::Neutron::Listenerv2 properties: loadbalancer: { get_resource: loadbalancer } protocol: HTTP protocol_port: { get_param: lb_port } loadbalancer: type: OS::Neutron::LoadBalancerV2 properties: vip_subnet: { get_resource: subnet } floating_ip: type: OS::Neutron::FloatingIP properties: floating_network: { get_param: public_net } port_id: { get_attr: [loadbalancer, vip, 'port_id'] } outputs: lburl: description: URL of the loadbalanced app value: str_replace: template: http://IP_ADDRESS:PORT params: IP_ADDRESS: { get_attr: [ floating_ip, floating_ip_address ] } PORT: { get_param: lb_port }

commit_message:
FirstApp - Shade key pair location

Adds a note that you may need to use the absolute path to avoid an IOerror.

Closes-Bug: #1555855
Change-Id: I18b1fdb896bb55da78b7ab0ac49e154520086beb

subject: gpfs: remove a race in deleting volumes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-14 05:55:14.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/gpfs.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e67110461afeb54c93e9af7ab2ad31a8bc304d8c', 'message': 'gpfs: remove a race in deleting volumes

"find" command may end with error if any of files in a target directory
is removed during its run. As we can/should ignore it and continue the
operation, we run "find" with -ignore_readdir_race option to stop
considering it an error.

Also, "find" runs with -print0 and -quit as it is a better practice.

Closes-bug: 1581670
Change-Id: Id26cb59d88082971465c8fcf0c150c858ab3bced
'}]
commit_message:
gpfs: remove a race in deleting volumes

"find" command may end with error if any of files in a target directory
is removed during its run. As we can/should ignore it and continue the
operation, we run "find" with -ignore_readdir_race option to stop
considering it an error.

Also, "find" runs with -print0 and -quit as it is a better practice.

Closes-bug: 1581670
Change-Id: Id26cb59d88082971465c8fcf0c150c858ab3bced
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/48/316348/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -ignore_readdir_race is to prevent the command from exiting # with nonzero RC when some files in the directory are removed # by other delete operations. -quit is to end the execution as # soon as we get one filename; it is not expected that two or # more filenames found. '-ignore_readdir_race', '-inum', inode, '-print0', '-quit', run_as_root=True) if out: fparent = out.split('\0', 1)[0]
deleted_lines: '-inum', inode, run_as_root=True) if out: fparent = out.split('\n', 1)[0]

  1) It checks that person who want to trace is trusted and knows

* Add initialization of osprofiler at start of serivce
  Currently that includes oslo.messaging notifer instance creation
  to send Ceilometer backend notifications.

commit_message:
Add OSprofiler support

* Add osprofiler wsgi middleware. This middleware is used for 2 things:
  1) It checks that person who wants to trace is trusted and knows
     secret HMAC key.
  2) It starts tracing in case of proper trace headers
     and adds first wsgi trace point, with info about HTTP request

* Add initialization of osprofiler at start of service
  Currently that includes oslo.messaging notifer instance creation
  to send Ceilometer backend notifications.

Neutron client change: Ic11796889075b2a0e589b70398fc4d4ed6f3ef7c

Co-authored-by: Ryan Moats <rmoats@us.ibm.com>
Depends-On: I5102eb46a7a377eca31375a0d64951ba1fdd035d
Closes-Bug: #1335640
DocImpact Add devref and operator documentation on how to use this
APIImpact
Change-Id: I7fa2ad57dc5763ce72cba6945ebcadef2188e8bd

commit_message:
Restart n-cpu after Ironic install

Ironic install initiates apache restart, it may cause nova-compute
failed to start.
This patch restart nova-compute after Ironic install for new phase.
And ensures that keystone is responding before starting n-cpu.

Related-Bug: 1537076

Change-Id: Id229617ec5cf2820c1033fd2c34fc160a75c46d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/79/318479/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(vsaienko) installing ironic service triggers apache restart, that # may cause nova-compute failure due to LP1537076 stop_nova_compute || true # NOTE(pas-ha) if nova compute failed before restart, .failure file # that was created will fail the service_check in the end of the deployment _clean_ncpu_failure start_nova_compute

subject: Enforce UUID of port/subnet ID for router interfaces
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 16:33:04.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/extensions/test_l3.py', 'neutron/db/l3_db.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/df80a6e73db2b5bd77b19d85634d7be0c00f39b0', 'message': 'Enforce UUID of port/subnet ID for router interfaces

The add_router_interface/remove_router_interface actions
are not subject to the typical attribute map validation
so the input values for port_id and subnet_id were not
being checked for UUID likeness. This lead to an ugly
traceback if a boolean value was present which could
fill logs with garbage if a tenant kept doing it.

This patch calls the API validator for UUIDs in the
_validate_interface_info function where we validate requests
to add_router_inferface and remove_router_interface.

Conflicts:
	neutron/db/l3_db.py

Change-Id: I0a0d3279a21c815fb78528860fc2a35c1d5a4e2d
Closes-Bug: #1584510
(cherry picked from commit 18280216cb7405856ba52f7eee0b1b214dcebd7b)
'}]
commit_message:
Enforce UUID of port/subnet ID for router interfaces

The add_router_interface/remove_router_interface actions
are not subject to the typical attribute map validation
so the input values for port_id and subnet_id were not
being checked for UUID likeness. This lead to an ugly
traceback if a boolean value was present which could
fill logs with garbage if a tenant kept doing it.

This patch calls the API validator for UUIDs in the
_validate_interface_info function where we validate requests
to add_router_inferface and remove_router_interface.

Conflicts:
	neutron/db/l3_db.py

Change-Id: I0a0d3279a21c815fb78528860fc2a35c1d5a4e2d
Closes-Bug: #1584510
(cherry picked from commit 18280216cb7405856ba52f7eee0b1b214dcebd7b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/46/320046/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for key in ('port_id', 'subnet_id'): if key not in interface_info: continue err = attributes._validate_uuid(interface_info[key]) if err: raise n_exc.BadRequest(resource='router', msg=err)

commit_message:
Change ansible image to kolla_toolbox

All the images follow the same naming schema where the container
name is part of the ansible variable name.  Currently, the
kolla_toolbox container is named ansible_image_full.  Change
this to match what the container name is.

Could impact operators who are specifying ansible_image_full
in globals.yml.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I9f0cbe4bd69ce17489310a1f5734a254e6ebe27b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/88/320088/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: image: "{{ kolla_toolbox_image_full }}"

subject: We should use multipath -l instead of multipath -ll
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-17 03:52:59.000000000', 'files': ['os_brick/initiator/connector.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-brick/commit/759a4fb82857fd946fb5e8e28c6c8564d43e7fc4', 'message': 'We should use multipath -l instead of multipath -ll

In initiator.connector.py, the function _get_multipath_device_map
is used for getting multipath device name and sdx device mapping.
But, the" multipath -ll "command is very time-consuming. Therefore,
in this function we should use "multipath -l "instead of it.
Also the functon _get_multipath_device_name.

This part of the code is modified by the patch proposed here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232846/
In the patch, add an utility to identify IQNs by using multipath device
map (/dev/sdX => /dev/mapper/XXX) generated by 'multipath -ll'. I think
'multipath -ll' is very time-consuming, especially there are lots of
multipath devices on the node . And we can get multipath device
map generated by 'multipath -l' without losing any infomation.

Change-Id: I5fb3a25901d3d470825f97346d03bb3f2047b93f
Closes-Bug: #1580830
'}]
commit_message:
We should use multipath -l instead of multipath -ll

In initiator.connector.py, the function _get_multipath_device_map
is used for getting multipath device name and sdx device mapping.
But, the" multipath -ll "command is very time-consuming. Therefore,
in this function we should use "multipath -l "instead of it.
Also the functon _get_multipath_device_name.

This part of the code is modified by the patch proposed here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232846/
In the patch, add an utility to identify IQNs by using multipath device
map (/dev/sdX => /dev/mapper/XXX) generated by 'multipath -ll'. I think
'multipath -ll' is very time-consuming, especially there are lots of
multipath devices on the node . And we can get multipath device
map generated by 'multipath -l' without losing any infomation.

Change-Id: I5fb3a25901d3d470825f97346d03bb3f2047b93f
Closes-Bug: #1580830
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/13/317213/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: out = self._run_multipath(['-l', out = self._run_multipath(['-l'], check_exit_code=[0, 1])[0] LOG.warn(_LW("Failed to parse the output of multipath -l."))
deleted_lines: out = self._run_multipath(['-ll', out = self._run_multipath(['-ll'], check_exit_code=[0, 1])[0] LOG.warn(_LW("Failed to parse the output of multipath -ll."))

commit_message:
We should use multipath -l instead of multipath -ll

In initiator.connector.py, the function _get_multipath_device_map
is used for getting multipath device name and sdx device mapping.
But, the" multipath -ll "command is very time-consuming. Therefore,
in this function we should use "multipath -l "instead of it.

Change-Id: I8c8891b74d6103f2dd85d9193daca1fcb5e95f6f
Closes-Bug: #1580830
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/95/315395/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: out = self._run_multipath(['-l'], check_exit_code=[0, 1])[0] LOG.warning(_LW("Failed to parse the output of multipath -l. "
deleted_lines: out = self._run_multipath(['-ll'], check_exit_code=[0, 1])[0] LOG.warning(_LW("Failed to parse the output of multipath -ll. "

commit_message:
Make README references to neutron.conf consistently

There are several mentions to change configuration parameter in
neutron.conf, this patch makes them consistently allover the
document.

Change-Id: I2141fcb3f4552eba05adf258f72a224a9fa69bb9
Signed-off-by: Antonio Ojea <aojea@midokura.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/93/318493/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The following entry in ``/etc/neutron/neutron.conf`` enables MidoNet as the Neutron plugin.in the DEFAULT section of `/etc/neutron/neutron.conf`:: [DEFAULT] service_plugins = midonet.neutron.services.gw_device.plugin.MidonetGwDeviceServicePluginTo configure it, add the following service plugin to the `service_plugins` list in the DEFAULT section of `/etc/neutron/neutron.conf`::

commit_message:
Added refs_map attribute to resource groups

This attribute produces a map of resource name to ID, suitable for
passing into a SoftwareDeploymentGroup servers input.

Change-Id: I9c9a2cd8f3f4c1fd50837c74bd49fc4dd4d06bcf
Partial-Bug: #1582837
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/12/318312/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_aggregate_refs_map(self): resg = self._create_dummy_stack() found = resg.FnGetAtt("refs_map") expected = {'0': 'ID-0', '1': 'ID-1'} self.assertEqual(expected, found)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-29 14:49:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth/commit/77447325051758db878c4d88d1858e23fcc2c8cd', 'message': "Use betamax hooks to mask fixture results

We cannot rely on native recorded fixtures with betamax,
because of two reasons: - betamax is recording cloud usernames
and passwords. If we run this into real clouds, that's a security
problem. We need to replace those by dummy users and passwords -
when keystone tokens are generated, they are recorded with a fixed
expiration time. That means, that tests are passing until the token
expire, but after that, tests are no longer valid because the
recorded token is in the past.

So need to use pre_record hook to alter the recorded results.
The hook has to update fixtures with 2 things: - mask user,
password and tenant for clouds - set a token expiration date in
the long future.

Closes-Bug: 1570384

commit_message:
Use betamax hooks to mask fixture results

We cannot rely on native recorded fixtures with betamax,
because of two reasons: - betamax is recording cloud usernames
and passwords. If we run this into real clouds, that's a security
problem. We need to replace those by dummy users and passwords -
when keystone tokens are generated, they are recorded with a fixed
expiration time. That means, that tests are passing until the token
expire, but after that, tests are no longer valid because the
recorded token is in the past.

So need to use pre_record hook to alter the recorded results.
The hook has to update fixtures with 2 things: - mask user,
password and tenant for clouds - set a token expiration date in
the long future.

Change-Id: I5d959ee9386fb0321e9d39c73792155acd6b4851
Closes-Bug: 1570384
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/33/311133/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneauth1.fixture import hooks serializer=None, record=False, pre_record_hook=hooks.pre_record_hook): self.pre_record_hook = pre_record_hook with betamax.Betamax.configure() as config: config.before_record(callback=fixture.pre_record_hook)

commit_message:
Rename [debug] section in config to [debug-group]

Rename [debug] section in config to [debug-group], so that it
won't shadow debug option in config.

Closes-Bug: #1584696
Change-Id: I3f4474ca11d772c63434b0208b9ef18767acf6bb

commit_message:
Adds an experimental config option [upgrade_levels]/conductor

This will cap the conductor RPC API version.
All RPC calls should only send messages which are compatible with
the RPC cap from the [upgrade_levels]/conductor. Users can set the
cap value as Ironic version like 'liberty' or future stable
releases(Mitaka) and numbered releases(4.x).

If no value is given, the version cap will be the
RPC_API_VERSION.

Change-Id: I8e72f786f7fc7ebc0477cb1ee8844572af536e3d
Implements: blueprint online-upgrade-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/55/253355/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfgCONF = cfg.CONF conductor_rpcapi_cap_options = [ cfg.StrOpt('condcutor_rpcapi_cap', choices=['liberty'], help=_('This will set the version cap for RPC messages ' 'sent to conductor services. All RPC call should ' 'only sent messages which is compatible with ' 'the rpc_cap.')) ] CONF.register_opts(conductor_rpcapi_cap_options, group='upgrade_levels') ... Liberty supports message version 1.31. So, any changes to existing methods in 1.x after that point should be done such that they can handle the version_cap being set to 1.31. VERSION_ALIASES = { 'liberty': '1.31', } # To simplify the logical, only keep compatible with major release # in VERSION_ALIASES, which could be used in production. version_cap = self.VERSION_ALIASES.get( CONF.upgrade_levels.condcutor_rpcapi_cap, self.RPC_API_VERSION) version_cap=version_cap,

commit_message:
Remove DB hook from Ironic API

Ironic API should only remotely read/write DB via Ironic Conductor
using object/RPC. So remove DB Hook and create a new RPC method
get_active_drivers(). This is part of ongoing work to prevent ironic-api
from directly accessing the database and bump RPC version to 1.33.

Driver-list API will return an empty list if there is no live conductor.
But this will block for a while, because this is depends on
rpc_response_timeout which is 60s by default.

Change-Id: Ia5675b37e3682c63e2cdb1b8fb5164107dca5578
Implements: blueprint online-upgrade-support
Partial-Bug: #1526283
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/97/243497/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: | 1.32 - Added get_active_driver_dict RPC_API_VERSION = '1.32' def get_active_driver_dict(self, context, topic=None): """Get a dictionary of active drivers with correspond conductors. :param context: request context. :param topic: RPC topic. Defaults to self.topic. :returns: a dictionary with <driver name>:set([host1, host2]) """ cctxt = self.client.prepare(topic=topic or self.topic, version='1.32') return cctxt.call(context, 'get_active_driver_dict')

subject: Fix cache decorator tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-19 02:56:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/64878d5af423c5947301a5d7a9bda5e4b0b7187c', 'message': "Fix cache decorator tests

The oslo.cache library's 'enabled' option started to work since this
patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/304688. And so Zaqar tests
related to cache decorator started to fail.

This patch makes cache decorator tests explicitly enable cache.

Change-Id: Ie1cb323e2108feb4dc508773eca4850c4dff086f
Closes-Bug: 1579974
(cherry picked from commit a066bca948906b83bd1c24352cae7673c7d5d230)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-19 03:43:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/4e6c98ae4c6c55e1d095f819a150928b7e44409e', 'message': "Fix cache decorator tests

The oslo.cache library's 'enabled' option started to work since this
patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/304688. And so Zaqar tests
related to cache decorator started to fail.

This patch makes cache decorator tests explicitly enable cache.

NOTE: This patch also restricts the flacon's verison otherwise this
patch can't pass the gate jobs. See patch
I7e8e97b73ec3e245580f07e62442caf0395d5745 for more details.

Closes-Bug: #1581189

Co-Authored-By: Fei Long Wang <flwang@catalyst.net.nz>

Closes-Bug: 1579974
(cherry picked from commit a066bca948906b83bd1c24352cae7673c7d5d230)

commit_message:
Fix cache decorator tests

The oslo.cache library's 'enabled' option started to work since this
patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/304688. And so Zaqar tests
related to cache decorator started to fail.

This patch makes cache decorator tests explicitly enable cache.

NOTE: This patch also restricts the flacon's verison otherwise this
patch can't pass the gate jobs. See patch
I7e8e97b73ec3e245580f07e62442caf0395d5745 for more details.

Closes-Bug: #1581189

Co-Authored-By: Fei Long Wang <flwang@catalyst.net.nz>
Co-Authored-By: wanghao <wanghao749@huawei.com>

Closes-Bug: 1579974
(cherry picked from commit a066bca948906b83bd1c24352cae7673c7d5d230)

Change-Id: Ie1cb323e2108feb4dc508773eca4850c4dff086f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/18/318418/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: conf.cache.enabled = True conf.cache.enabled = True

commit_message:
Use globals for auth_uri lookups

public_auth_uri, internal_auth_uri, and admin_identity_uri are used in
many places, but are each looked up and calculated on their own. This makes
it difficult to ensure consistency, or over ride it if desired.

Here we move from the individual calculations and instead propogate the
paramaters into hiera so that we can use the pre-created values. At the same
time, we look to see if we already received this structure in the event
that they where overridden.

Closes-bug: #1567143
Signed-off-by: Andrew Woodward <awoodward@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I90d8d030d345b628432fc6ee8de19a656ea532ea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/30/304230/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note(Xarses): Because of lore, neutron auth_uri is admin_uri + version # https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1567694 $admin_auth_uri = hiera('admin_auth_uri') $keystone_auth_version = hiera('keystone_auth_version') $neutron_auth_url = "${admin_auth_uri}/${keystone_auth_version}"

commit_message:
Introduce counter against premature split brain detection

If RabbitMQ process which we consider master dies, Pacemaker will
detect the failure only on the next monitor call. Meanwhile slave
processes might find that they are disconnected from the master and
hence should restart in order to avoid split brain, resulting in
complete cluster downtime. In order to avoid such issue, we allow
a small number of 'split brain' checks to fail, giving Pacemaker
time to discover failed master and react.

Related-Bug: #1559136
Change-Id: I2902fa13a36ff111691df06bf31076eae9074d30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/70/304070/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails_default=5: ${OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails=${OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails_default}}<parameter name="max_out_of_cluster_fails" unique="0" required="0"> <longdesc lang="en"> In order to detect split brain the script checks that current RabbitMQ node is connected to the master one. We declare current node to be split only if max_out_of_cluster_fails checks in a row fail. We allow several checks to fail without action in order to distinguish split brain and master node failure. </longdesc> <shortdesc lang="en">Fail only if that many checks found us running disconnected with master</shortdesc> <content type="string" default="${OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails_default}" /> </parameter> # Get crm_attr_name value from Pacemaker # Increase it by 1 # Update Pacemaker value # Return the updated value via stdout increase_and_return_pacemaker_param() { local crm_attr_name=$1 local count count=`crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name $crm_attr_name --query 2>/dev/null` if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then # the crm_attribute exited with error. In that case most probably it printed garbage # instead of the number we need. So defensively assume that it is zero. count=0 else count=`echo "${count}" | awk '{print $3}' | awk -F "=" '{print $2}' | sed -e '/(null)/d'` fi count=$((count+1)) # There is a slight chance that this piece of code will be executed twice simultaneously. # As a result, $crm_attr_name's value will be one less than it should be. But we don't need # precise calculation here. ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name $crm_attr_name --update $count echo $count } count=$(increase_and_return_pacemaker_param $crm_attr_name) count=$(increase_and_return_pacemaker_param "rabbit_split_brain_counter") if [ count -lt $OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails ]; then ocf_log warn "${LH} rabbit node possibly is running out of the cluster. $count out of max. $OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails latest checks found us disconnected from the master. Doing nothing for now." else # Rabbit is running but is not connected to master # Failing to avoid split brain ocf_log err "${LH} rabbit node is running out of the cluster. $count out of max. $OCF_RESKEY_max_out_of_cluster_fails latest checks found us disconnected from the master. Returning error to be restarted by Pacemaker." rc=$OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit_split_brain_counter' --update '0'

In that case most probably it printed garbage # instead of the number we need. So defensively assume that it is zero. count=0 fi count=`echo "${count}" | awk '{print $3}' | awk -F "=" '{print $2}' | sed -e '/(null)/d'` count=$((count+1)) # There is a slight chance that this piece of code will be executed twice simultaneously. # As a result, $crm_attr_name's value will be one less than it should be. But we don't need # precise calculation here. ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name $crm_attr_name --update $count # Rabbit is running but is not connected to master # Failing to avoid split brain ocf_log err "${LH} rabbit node is running out of the cluster" rc=$OCF_ERR_GENERIC

subject: Rank master score based on start time
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-15 13:39:33.000000000', 'files': ['files/fuel-ha-utils/ocf/rabbitmq'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/3ae2199a4a4d81c29ac88b2d1c041f533412b0dd', 'message': "Rank master score based on start time

Right now we assign 1000 to the oldest nodes and 1 to others. That
creates a problem when Master restarts and no node is promoted until
that node starts back. In that case the returned node will have score
of 1, like all other slaves and Pacemaker will select to promote it
again. The node is clean empty and afterwards other slaves join to
it, wiping their data as well. As a result, we loose all the messages.

The new algorithm actually ranks nodes, not just selects the oldest
one. It also maintains the invariant that if node A started later
than node B, then node A score must be smaller than that of
node B. As a result, freshly started node has no chance of being
selected in preference to older node. If several nodes start
simultaneously, among them an older node might temporarily receive
lower score than a younger one, but that is neglectable.

Also remove resource-stickiness meta parameter from RabbitMQ resource
configuration. We actually don't need RabbitMQ resource try to stick
to a node after failures. Quite on the contrary, master should
migrate to preserve data on alive nodes.

Finally, remove any action on demote or demote notification - all of
these duplicate actions done in stop or stop notification. With these
removed, changing master on a running cluster does not affect RabbitMQ
cluster in any way - we just declare another node master and that is
it.

Closes-Bug: #1559136
Change-Id: I2ee629eb07a6145647211da4dbe186aa9c45f61d
"}]
commit_message:
Rank master score based on start time

Right now we assign 1000 to the oldest nodes and 1 to others. That
creates a problem when Master restarts and no node is promoted until
that node starts back. In that case the returned node will have score
of 1, like all other slaves and Pacemaker will select to promote it
again. The node is clean empty and afterwards other slaves join to
it, wiping their data as well. As a result, we loose all the messages.

The new algorithm actually ranks nodes, not just selects the oldest
one. It also maintains the invariant that if node A started later
than node B, then node A score must be smaller than that of
node B. As a result, freshly started node has no chance of being
selected in preference to older node. If several nodes start
simultaneously, among them an older node might temporarily receive
lower score than a younger one, but that is neglectable.

Also remove resource-stickiness meta parameter from RabbitMQ resource
configuration. We actually don't need RabbitMQ resource try to stick
to a node after failures. Quite on the contrary, master should
migrate to preserve data on alive nodes.

Finally, remove any action on demote or demote notification - all of
these duplicate actions done in stop or stop notification. With these
removed, changing master on a running cluster does not affect RabbitMQ
cluster in any way - we just declare another node master and that is
it.

Closes-Bug: #1559136
Change-Id: I2ee629eb07a6145647211da4dbe186aa9c45f61d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/31/306431/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: get_node_attr() { local value value=$(crm_attribute -N $1 -l reboot --name "$2" --query 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $3}' | awk -F "=" '{print $2}' | sed -e '/(null)/d') if [ -z "$value" -o "$value" = "(null)" ] ; then value=0 echo $value } get_node_start_time() { get_node_attr $1 'rabbit-start-time' } get_node_master_score() { get_node_attr $1 'master-p_rabbitmq-server' master_score 100 master_score 100 fi # Recounting our master score ocf_log info "${LH} preparing to update master score for node" local our_start_time local new_score local node_start_time local node_score our_start_time=$(get_node_start_time $THIS_PCMK_NODE) if [ $our_start_time -eq 0 ]; then new_score=100 else new_score=10000 for node in $(get_alive_pacemaker_nodes_but $THIS_PCMK_NODE) node_start_time=$(get_node_start_time $node) node_score=$(get_node_master_score $node) ocf_log info "${LH} comparing our start time ($our_start_time) with $node ($node_start_time), which score is $node_score" if [ $node_start_time -ne 0 -a $node_score -ne 0 -a $node_start_time -lt $our_start_time ]; then new_score=$((node_score - 10 < new_score ? node_score - 10 : new_score )) fi if [ "$new_score" -ne "$(get_node_master_score $THIS_PCMK_NODE)" ]; then master_score $new_score ocf_log info "${LH} action skipped."
deleted_lines: srv_uptime() { local stime stime=$( crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit-start-time' --query 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $3}' | awk -F "=" '{print $2}' | sed -e '/(null)/d' ) if [ -z "${stime}" -o "${stime}" = "(null)" ] ; then echo 0 else echo $(( $(now) - ${stime} )) return $OCF_SUCCESS master_score 1 # minimal positive master-score for this node. master_score 1 local nodelist local max local our_uptime local node_uptime elif [ $rc -ne $OCF_RUNNING_MASTER ] ; then ocf_log info "${LH} preparing to update master score for node" our_uptime=$(srv_uptime) nodelist=$(get_alive_pacemaker_nodes_but $THIS_PCMK_NODE) max=1 for node in $nodelist node_start_time=`crm_attribute -N $node -l reboot --name 'rabbit-start-time' --query 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $3}' | awk -F "=" '{print $2}' | sed -e '/(null)/d'` if [ -z "${node_start_time}" -o "${node_start_time}" = "(null)" ] ; then node_uptime=0 else node_uptime=$(( $(now) - ${node_start_time} )) fi ocf_log info "${LH} comparing our uptime (${our_uptime}) with $node (${node_uptime})" if [ ${our_uptime} -lt ${node_uptime} ] then max=1 break else # When uptime is equal, accept the existing master - if any - as the oldest node is_master $node status_master=$? if [ $status_master -eq 0 ] ; then max=1 ocf_log info "${LH} Found the oldest master node $node with uptime (${node_uptime})" break else max=0 fi if [ $max -eq 0 ] then ocf_log info "${LH} we are the oldest node" master_score 1000 fi if [ "${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_type}" = 'pre' ] ; then # PRE- anything notify section case "$OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_operation" in promote) ocf_log info "${LH} pre-promote begin." my_host "$OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_promote_uname" rc=$? if [ $rc -eq $OCF_SUCCESS ] ; then nodelist=$(get_all_pacemaker_nodes) for i in $nodelist do ocf_log info "${LH} Deleting master attribute for node ${i}" ocf_run crm_attribute -N $i -l reboot --name 'rabbit-master' --delete done ocf_log info "${LH} pre-promote end." fi ;; *) ;; esac fi demote) # if rabbitmq-server stops on any another node, we should remove it from cluster (as ordinary operation) ocf_log info "${LH} post-demote begin." # Report not running, if the list of nodes being demoted reported empty if [ -z "${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_demote_uname}" ] ; then ocf_log warn "${LH} there are no nodes being demoted reported on post-demote. The resource will be restarted." ocf_log info "${LH} post-demote end." return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC fi my_host "${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_demote_uname}" rc=$? if [ $rc -ne $OCF_SUCCESS ] ; then # On ohter nodes processing the post-demote, make sure the demoted node will be forgotten unjoin_nodes_from_cluster "${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_demote_uname}" else # Wait for synced state first ocf_log info "${LH} waiting $((OCF_RESKEY_stop_time/2)) to sync" wait_sync $((OCF_RESKEY_stop_time/2)) # On the nodes being demoted, reset the master score ocf_log info "${LH} resetting the master score." master_score 0 ocf_log info "${LH} Deleting start time attribute" ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit-start-time' --delete ocf_log info "${LH} Deleting master attribute" ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit-master' --delete ocf_log info "${LH} master was demoted. stopping RabbitMQ app." stop_rmq_server_app rc2=$? if [ $rc2 -ne $OCF_SUCCESS ] ; then ocf_log err "${LH} RMQ-server app can't be stopped on post-demote. Master resource is failed" ocf_log info "${LH} post-demote end." exit $OCF_FAILED_MASTER fi fi ocf_log info "${LH} post-demote end." ;; if [ "${OCF_RESKEY_debug}" = 'true' ] ; then d=`date '+%Y%m%d %H:%M:%S'` echo $d >> /tmp/rmq-demote.log env >> /tmp/rmq-demote.log echo "$d [demote] start='${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_start_uname}' stop='${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_stop_uname}' active='${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_active_uname}' inactive='${OCF_RESKEY_CRM_meta_notify_inactive_uname}'" >> /tmp/rmq-ocf.log fi ocf_log info "${LH} action begin." get_monitor rc=$? case "$rc" in "$OCF_RUNNING_MASTER") # Running as master. Normal, expected behavior. ocf_log warn "${LH} Resource is currently running as Master" ocf_log info "${LH} Deleting master attribute" ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit-master' --delete ocf_log info "${LH} Deleting start timestamp" ocf_run crm_attribute -N $THIS_PCMK_NODE -l reboot --name 'rabbit-start-time' --delete # Wait for synced state first ocf_log info "${LH} waiting $((OCF_RESKEY_stop_time/2)) to sync" wait_sync $((OCF_RESKEY_stop_time/2)) stop_rmq_server_app rc=$? ;; "$OCF_SUCCESS") # Alread running as slave. Nothing to do. ocf_log warn "${LH} Resource is currently running as Slave" rc=$OCF_SUCCESS ;; "$OCF_FAILED_MASTER") # Master failed and being demoted. ocf_log err "${LH} Demoting of a failed Master." ocf_log info "${LH} action end." exit $OCF_FAILED_MASTER ;; "$OCF_NOT_RUNNING") ocf_log warn "${LH} Try to demote currently not running resource. Nothing to do." rc=$OCF_SUCCESS ;; "$OCF_ERR_GENERIC") ocf_log err "${LH} Error while demote. Stopping resource." action_stop rc=$? ;; *) # Failed resource. Let the cluster manager recover. ocf_log err "${LH} Unexpected error, cannot demote" ocf_log info "${LH} action end." exit $rc ;; esac # transform master RMQ-server to slave ocf_log info "${LH} action end."

commit_message:
add a standard topic to all constraint updates

Use a standard topic for all constraint updates to make them easier to
spot in the review queue.

Change-Id: I7bedd35b87aa3d6a8bb9901d3b3f9ef67f0f705a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/07/318007/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: fix the way we gather metadata
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-19 19:47:11.000000000', 'files': ['release_from_yaml.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/release-tools/commit/2def375c729d5c4258c24a1ee15f09b983f461b4', 'message': 'fix the way we gather metadata

Sometimes patches merge into the openstack/releases repo without a
separate merge commit. In those cases, look at the actual patch for the
metadata we need.

Change-Id: Ie3f9d98e334b9f018ceab53d62700c826c5ff13f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix the way we gather metadata

Sometimes patches merge into the openstack/releases repo without a
separate merge commit. In those cases, look at the actual patch for the
metadata we need.

Change-Id: Ie3f9d98e334b9f018ceab53d62700c826c5ff13f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/13/318913/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if git show --no-patch --pretty=format:%P | grep -q ' '; then # multiple parents, look at the submitted patch instead of the # merge commit parent=$(git show --no-patch --pretty=format:%P | cut -f2 -d' ') else # single parent, look at the current patch parent='' fi

subject: Restart dsnmasq on any network subnet change

commit_message:
Restart dsnmasq on any network subnet change

When a new subnet is added to a network, the network cache
is updated with the list of subnets regardless of which ones
have DHCP enabled. This changes the index order of the subnet
list which means that the tags used for each subnet change.

This means we must restart the process because the opts file
will be using different tags than the process args. This patch
implements that change. It also sorts the subnets on the RPC
side so the agent indexes don't change if subnets aren't
added/deleted.

The previous logic was only restarting the process when DHCP
enabled subnets changed, which meant that adding a DHCP disabled
subnet would break the association between the opts file tags and
the process arg tags, which led to the reported bug.

Closes-Bug: #1581918
Change-Id: If1452c0e8fe95eb94cd78c7a05b57aead75662b5
(cherry picked from commit e45add7b07e5c72c43047d18e10af1c4ae307b0f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/39/319139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Restart dsnmasq on any network subnet change

When a new subnet is added to a network, the network cache
is updated with the list of subnets regardless of which ones
have DHCP enabled. This changes the index order of the subnet
list which means that the tags used for each subnet change.

This means we must restart the process because the opts file
will be using different tags than the process args. This patch
implements that change. It also sorts the subnets on the RPC
side so the agent indexes don't change if subnets aren't
added/deleted.

The previous logic was only restarting the process when DHCP
enabled subnets changed, which meant that adding a DHCP disabled
subnet would break the association between the opts file tags and
the process arg tags, which led to the reported bug.

Closes-Bug: #1581918
Change-Id: If1452c0e8fe95eb94cd78c7a05b57aead75662b5
(cherry picked from commit e45add7b07e5c72c43047d18e10af1c4ae307b0f)

commit_message:
Fix untranslated strings in ng-instance

At the moment, in Details tab, Instance Name and Count is untranslated.
This patch will fix it.

Change-Id: I40a9aba3b75392ad5206e644f47d37bf9fec86ad
Closes-Bug: #1582710

commit_message:
Adding warning to Launch Instance when no availability zones

When there are no avaiability zones, display a warning message.

The bug report doesn't indicate whether we should do anything else (such as
stop the user from proceeding) so it just shows the warning in the place
of the drop-down.

Change-Id: Id3371928cead332c0ec39d243c7f2ad2d99ad834
Closes-Bug: 1434275

commit_message:
Fix is_valid_cidr raises TypeError

is_valid_cidr raises TypeError if invalid addr type is passed.
Caught TypeError to return False if addr type is other than
expected.

Change-Id: I2bb6070e96eb07a47aab12eeef2840ca4f6abc1e
Closes-Bug: #1584599

commit_message:
Keep backward compatibility for openstack port create

openstack port create was introduced in Newton. Keep backwards
compatibility in places that are used on Mitaka code during upgrades.

Change-Id: I32da9f291bdfa18038a9f5412a06476b5da29f08
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/32/319232/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: port_id=$(neutron port-create ${ironic_net_id} | grep " id " | get_field 2) # NOTE(vsaienko) openstack port create was introduced in Newton. # Since the function is used during upgrade, it should be backward compatible with Mitaka. # Switch to openstack port create in Ocata release. #port_id=$(openstack port create --network ${ironic_net_id} temp_port -c id -f value)
deleted_lines: port_id=$(openstack port create --network ${ironic_net_id} temp_port -c id -f value)

commit_message:
Enable notification messaging pools

Adds a 'notification_pool' option in the [listener] configuration
section. This is an alternative to adding a separate topic that will be
recommended for the Newton release following more testing; for now it is
an optional alternative.

To enable:

  [listener]
  notifications_pool = searchlight-listener

You will see a rabbitmq queue named searchlight-listener. Note that your
topic must match the service notifications_topic setting, whether it be
the default of 'notifications' or 'searchlight_indexer'.

Closes-Bug: #1583215
Change-Id: Ie40876e88059d0326efa0b4abaa76b8b64f0b86b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/67/318967/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: There areithen two ways to configure the service to send notifications that Searchlight can receive. The recommended method is to use notification pools, touched on in the `messaging documentation`_. .. _`messaging documentation`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.messaging/notification_listener.html Notification pools ################## A notification messaging pool allows additional listeners to receive messages on an existing topic. By default notifications use a topic named `notifications`. To have ``listener.py`` eavesdrop, run it with an argument indicating a pool name:: . ~/devstack/openrc admin admin ./test-scripts/listener.py neutron test-notifications Adding a separate topic ####################### In the same config file (``/etc/neutron/neutron.conf``) the following line (again, under the ``[DEFAULT]`` section) will cause neutron to output notifications to a topic named ``searchlight_indexer``:: Using the results #################

commit_message:
Fix deleting application

Multi application in environment could be removed one by one.
but last one application could not be removed.
This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I5a022052347ea11a787659c2de2d77d99b003f7b
Closes-Bug: #1511645
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/64/287664/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: if not body: msg = _('Request body is empty: please, provide ' 'application object model') LOG.error(msg) raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg)

commit_message:
Add resource provider tables to the api database

This just mirrors the DB schema baked in the cell DB up to the API DB.

Related to blueprint generic-resource-pools

Change-Id: I8324a8b9c5ba640e48b6d6e426f7d8073a1b962b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/315681/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy import Unicode class ResourceProvider(API_BASE): """Represents a mapping to a providers of resources.""" __tablename__ = "resource_providers" __table_args__ = ( Index('resource_providers_uuid_idx', 'uuid'), schema.UniqueConstraint('uuid', name='uniq_resource_providers0uuid'), Index('resource_providers_name_idx', 'name'), schema.UniqueConstraint('name', name='uniq_resource_providers0name') ) id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False) uuid = Column(String(36), nullable=False) name = Column(Unicode(200), nullable=True) generation = Column(Integer, default=0) can_host = Column(Integer, default=0) class Inventory(API_BASE): """Represents a quantity of available resource.""" __tablename__ = "inventories" __table_args__ = ( Index('inventories_resource_provider_id_idx', 'resource_provider_id'), Index('inventories_resource_class_id_idx', 'resource_class_id'), Index('inventories_resource_provider_resource_class_idx', 'resource_provider_id', 'resource_class_id'), schema.UniqueConstraint('resource_provider_id', 'resource_class_id', name='uniq_inventories0resource_provider_resource_class') ) id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False) resource_provider_id = Column(Integer, nullable=False) resource_class_id = Column(Integer, nullable=False) total = Column(Integer, nullable=False) reserved = Column(Integer, nullable=False) min_unit = Column(Integer, nullable=False) max_unit = Column(Integer, nullable=False) step_size = Column(Integer, nullable=False) allocation_ratio = Column(Float, nullable=False) resource_provider = orm.relationship( "ResourceProvider", primaryjoin=('and_(Inventory.resource_provider_id == ' 'ResourceProvider.id)'), foreign_keys=resource_provider_id) class Allocation(API_BASE): """A use of inventory.""" __tablename__ = "allocations" __table_args__ = ( Index('allocations_resource_provider_class_used_idx', 'resource_provider_id', 'resource_class_id', 'used'), Index('allocations_resource_class_id_idx', 'resource_class_id'), Index('allocations_consumer_id_idx', 'consumer_id') ) id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False) resource_provider_id = Column(Integer, nullable=False) consumer_id = Column(String(36), nullable=False) resource_class_id = Column(Integer, nullable=False) used = Column(Integer, nullable=False)

commit_message:
Add updated_at field to app data model

Currently updated_at field is missing in the app show
response. This change adds field to the data model.

Change-Id: I1f8203d3c716991c64051fdd584a8d9c1c769463
Partial-Bug: #1583686

commit_message:
Re-organize tacker sample templates

Tacker TOSCA templates are currently buried under tacker/devstack.
These samples templates are applicable for the whole project and they
are not related specifically to the devstack installation. Also,
segregate the new TOSCA parser based templates from the legacy ones
for easier deprecation when the time comes.

Change-Id: I35547335baf6827e6b7b10702d05276343d8ce75
Closes-Bug: #1579251

commit_message:
Add possibility to provide auth token via CLI

Python part of Manilaclient does support auth by token, but
CLI part does not. Therefore, add two new optional args
with related env vars:
--os-token [OS_TOKEN]
--bypass-url [MANILACLIENT_BYPASS_URL]

Also, disable checks for other auth data if these two are provided.

Change-Id: I567294dfb61e702410c3f0fadc15a04667075434
Closes-Bug: #1572095
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient refs/changes/94/316994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Refactored the update method in api.py for vol obj

The update method now checks if volume is ovo, if not, it converts
it at the start. It makes sure the update method works whether a
volume is dict or ovo

Change-Id: I82be27bcd370a783c33f3d561af8315589437b96
Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-object
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/05/309605/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.db.sqlalchemy import api as dbapi # NOTE(karthikp): Making sure volume is always oslo-versioned # If not, we convert it at the start of the update method if not isinstance(volume, objects_base.CinderObject): db_volume = dbapi.get_volume(context, volume['id']) volume = objects.Volume._from_db_object(context, volume, db_volume) if volume.status == 'maintenance': volume.update(fields) volume.save() LOG.info(_LI("Volume updated successfully."), resource=volume)
deleted_lines: if volume['status'] == 'maintenance': # NOTE(thangp): Update is called by various APIs, some of which are # not yet using oslo_versionedobjects. We need to handle the case # where volume is either a dict or an oslo_versionedobject. if isinstance(volume, objects_base.CinderObject): volume.update(fields) volume.save() LOG.info(_LI("Volume updated successfully."), resource=volume) else: vref = self.db.volume_update(context, volume['id'], fields) LOG.info(_LI("Volume updated successfully."), resource=vref)

commit_message:
Fix coverage option and execution

--coverage-package-name option was no longer supported by 'testr'[1].
This commit replaces from 'testr' to 'test' as coverage option.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/217847/

Change-Id: I0430fd696752c1cd8e33bb2d146e08e442ebc3f8

commit_message:
remove python 2.6 trove classifier

OpenStack projects are no longer being tested under Python 2.6, so
remove the trove classifier implying that this project supports 2.6.

Change-Id: Ibbf905b70d8040cbf2a5f0a35e79c304f247f726

commit_message:
remove verbose option in devstack plugin

This option is deprecated in Mitaka and has been removed in Newton,
and its default value is True already. Let's remove it.

Change-Id: I167713165bd96a4ccd423976f8fcad5ff8fc399c

commit_message:
Fix falcon confilct in requirements.txt

Since hook feature has removed after 1.0.0, using
middleware instead of it, but for the compatibility
with old version, we support them both now.

Closes-Bug: #1583358

Change-Id: Ie182017d982efd727c63634b2a168dadd41711e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/29/318529/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #NOTE(wanghao): Since hook feature has removed after 1.0.0, using #middleware instead of it, but for the compatibility with old version, #we support them both now. Hook way can be removed after falcon #version must be bigger than 1.0.0 in requirements. if falcon.__version__ >= "1.0.0": middleware = [FuncMiddleware(hook) for hook in self.before_hooks] self.app = falcon.API(middleware=middleware) else: self.app = falcon.API(before=self.before_hooks)
deleted_lines: middleware = [FuncMiddleware(hook) for hook in self.before_hooks] self.app = falcon.API(middleware=middleware)

added_lines: def test_unmanage_volume(self): client = self.mock_client.return_value client.__enter__.return_value = client with mock.patch.object(self.driver.rbd.RBD(), 'rename') as mock_rename: unmanaged = 'unmanaged-' + self.volume_a.name self.driver.unmanage(self.volume_a) mock_rename.assert_called_with( client.ioctx, self.volume_a.name, unmanaged) @common_mocks def test_unmanage_no_exist_volume(self): client = self.mock_client.return_value client.__enter__.return_value = client self.mock_rbd.RBD.return_value.rename.side_effect = ( MockImageNotFoundException) self.assertIsNone(self.driver.unmanage(self.volume_a)) self.assertEqual(RAISED_EXCEPTIONS, [self.mock_rbd.ImageNotFound]) @common_mocks

commit_message:
Correct cinder 'exchange' value

Cinder, unlike most other services, doesn't override the default
'exchange' when messaging is configured and runs instead on the
'openstack' exchange.

As a separate patch we should make the exchange value configurable as
theoretically it can be changed even though most services don't support
doing so currently.

Change-Id: I761e4f2e2d4087a53097dab44c624e16bf694ff5
Closes-Bug: #1583659
(cherry picked from commit f2ed51babed12c6cae2bdd7b6ee492200b2f994c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/20/320020/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Unlike most services cinder doesn't override the exchange name from # the oslo.messaging default return ['openstack']

subject: DevStack: Support setting default quotas
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 13:17:22.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh', 'devstack/settings'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/bef53dbe937b5903569aeaaba44f5663ef6cd369', 'message': 'DevStack: Support setting default quotas

As tempest is creating and deleting zones, it does not wait
for all zones to be deleted before moving onto the next test.

This can lead to having a large number of pending delete zones
which consume all/most of the default quotas, and tests begin
failing.

By setting the default quotas higher in DevStack, we allow the
tests to proceed.

Change-Id: I3652bb06724fb8b89bb341c9d9f61b1dde056119
'}]
commit_message:
DevStack: Support setting default quotas

As tempest is creating and deleting zones, it does not wait
for all zones to be deleted before moving onto the next test.

This can lead to having a large number of pending delete zones
which consume all/most of the default quotas, and tests begin
failing.

By setting the default quotas higher in DevStack, we allow the
tests to proceed.

Change-Id: I3652bb06724fb8b89bb341c9d9f61b1dde056119
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/28/319928/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix "Codec can't encode characters"

Headers were encoded in HTTPClient, but when glance client started
to use SessionClient this functionality was lost.

This commit replaces static method "encode_headers" from HTTPClient
and makes it a common function, that SessionClient can use when
converting image meta to headers.


Change-Id: If9f8020220d2a0431b4241b38b9c83c09c0d75cb
Closes-bug: #1574587
(cherry picked from commit 9329ef0bc40375cd9b115415e10baf89789f56f0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient refs/changes/69/319969/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def encode_headers(headers): """Encodes headers. Note: This should be used right before sending anything out. :param headers: Headers to encode :returns: Dictionary with encoded headers' names and values """ return dict((encodeutils.safe_encode(h), encodeutils.safe_encode(v)) for h, v in six.iteritems(headers) if v is not None) headers = encode_headers(headers) headers = encode_headers(kwargs.pop('headers', {}))
deleted_lines: @staticmethod def encode_headers(headers): """Encodes headers. Note: This should be used right before sending anything out. :param headers: Headers to encode :returns: Dictionary with encoded headers' names and values """ return dict((encodeutils.safe_encode(h), encodeutils.safe_encode(v)) for h, v in six.iteritems(headers) if v is not None) headers = self.encode_headers(headers) headers = kwargs.pop('headers', {})

commit_message:
Fix py34 gate job

Add a configuration wrapper to avoid reentrant call to __getattr__()
in copy.copy(conf) on Python 3.x which is causing Zaqar's py34 gate job
failure randomly. The code is copied from Cinder, see the similar fix
in Cinder: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/280241/

Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan<wangxiyuan@huawei.com>
Co-Authored-By: Wang Hao<wanghao749@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I627b96f00e5b05993b8f4f586ea216214d5f1a5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/34/317134/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: conf = copy.deepcopy(conf)

commit_message:
Add a kolla-kubernetes quickstart guide

This is a first pass at the quickstart guide.  We can add
more as the CLI develops further.

Change-Id: I6e6ac3f6faf2a62a3f4e12e8bf1d07dc45f43b45
Partially-implements: blueprint documentation-initialization
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/70/319570/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. quickstart: ================================= Kolla Kubernetes Quickstart Guide ================================= Dependencies ============ ===================== =========== =========== ========================= Component Min Version Max Version Comment ===================== =========== =========== ========================= Ansible 1.9.4 < 2.0.0 On deployment host Docker 1.10.0 < 1.11.0 On target nodes Docker Python 1.6.0 none On target nodes Python Jinja2 2.8.0 none On deployment host Kubernetes 1.2.4 none On all hosts ===================== =========== =========== ========================= Since Docker is required to build images as well as be present on all deployed targets, the kolla-kubernetes community recommends installing the official Docker, Inc. packaged version of Docker for maximum stability and compatibility. .. NOTE:: Docker 1.11.0 is not compatible with Kubernetes do to some issues in Docker. The below command will install the lasted docker and revert back to 1.10.3. :: curl -sSL https://get.docker.io | bash # CentOS sudo yum downgrade -y docker-engine-1.10.3-1.el7.centos # Ubuntu sudo apt-get remove docker-engine sudo apt-get install docker-engine=1.10.3-1 Docker needs to run with MountFlags=shared in order for Neutron to function in 'thin' containers. Change MountFlags from slave to shared and restart Docker. :: # Edit /usr/lib/system/systemd/docker.service MountFlags=shared systemctl daemon-reload systemctl start docker HyperCube ========= HyperKube is series of containers that will run all the needed Kubernetes services locally. If you prefer to run Kubernetes in containers follow the :doc:`kubernetes-all -in-one`.

commit_message:
Document a kubernetes allinone setup

Use hypercude, kubernetes running in a container, to
setup an allinone environment.

Change-Id: I9207f85e396f4aa14128dc4ea1457621295998f8
Partially-implements: blueprint documentation-initialization

added_lines: Kolla Kubernetes All In One Guide ================================= Single-node Kubernetes setup ---------------------------- http://kubernetes.io/docs/getting-started-guides/docker/ The hypekube container runs the following services: - kube-apiproxy (The master) - kublet (Starts/Stops services & syncs config) - kube-scheduler (Resource manager) - kube-controller-manger (Manages desired state by monitoring the RC) - kube-proxy (Exposes the services on each node) :: docker run --volume=/:/rootfs:ro --volume=/sys:/sys:ro --volume=/var/lib/docker/:/var/lib/docker:rw --volume=/var/lib/kubelet/:/var/lib/kubelet:rw --volume=/var/run:/var/run:rw --net=host --pid=host --privileged=true --name=kubelet -d gcr.io/google_containers/hyperkube-amd64:v1.2.0 /hyperkube kubelet --containerized --hostname-override="127.0.0.1" --address="0.0.0.0" --api-servers=http://localhost:8080 --config=/etc/kubernetes/manifests --cluster-dns=10.0.0.10 --cluster-domain=cluster.local --allow-privileged=true --v=2 Download kubectl. :: wget http://storage.googleapis.com/kubernetes-release/release/v1.2.0/bin/linux/amd64/kubectl chmod 755 kubectl PATH=$PATH:`pwd` Try it out. :: kubectl get nodes

oidc: fix typo on class name

The class name was wrong, therefore it was not possible to load it from
the defined entry point. This change fixes it.

commit_message:
Get and inject provisioning system credentials

Credentials are needed to enroll a machine into an Identity
Management service. The process of generating these credentials
needs to be done synchronously before the instance is created so
the generated credentials are available to both the instance and
the provisioning system. This needs to be done before the instance
is booted so enrollment can be done in the cloud-init first boot
so the process can be automated.

Change-Id: Ia5146e4f36cefe51ab382e8efe96d6e84f1df983
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/55/305455/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Get and inject provisioning system credentials ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/get-provision-credentials Credentials are needed to enroll a machine into an Identity Management service. The process of generating these credentials needs to be done synchronously before the instance is created so the generated credentials are available to both the instance and the provisioning system. This needs to be done before the instance is booted so enrollment can be done in the cloud-init first boot so the process can be automated. Problem description =================== There is no way to generate credentials and inject them into an instance with no user intervention before it has booted the first time. Use Cases --------- You have an Identity Management system that hosts can enroll into to obtain access to those identities. In order to enroll a credential is required. This can take the form of administrator credentials or a One-Time Password (OTP). You want newly generated instances to automatically enroll so the administrator doesn't need to log into each one and enroll it. To do so an OTP is required. The credentials may need to be provided by the Identity Management system so a mechanism is needed before the instance is created to call out to the Identity Management system to get those credentials and then pass them into the newly generated instance. cloud-init or a user-provided package can do the automatic enrollment. Proposed change =============== Add a call to a new provisioning driver just before the instance is generated (in _do_build_and_run_instance()). The return value of this call, a string, will be added to the injected_files list in a hardcoded location: /root/openstack_credentials. A ProvisionDriver base class will be provided which offers two methods: __init__(): to initialize any long-term connections to the Identity Management system. A failure to initialize is not a fatal error. get_credentials(project_name, request_spec): get the OTP or other credentials from the Identity Management system and return them as a plain string. If None is returned then no credentials were generated and no file is injected. Exceptions may be raised by the driver. The arguments passed into get_credentials are simple python objects. project_name is a string type and request_spec is a dictionary containing instance information like the hostname and metadata. The project name is needed to support multi-tenancy. The hostname and metadata are useful to the Identity Management system to decide whether and how to generate credentials. A new configuration option will be added to specify which driver to load containing the implementation class. This will be None by default. It is the responsibility of this driver to make credentials available. It is still up to the end-user/operator to make use of them via cloud-init or user-provided packages which execute during first boot. Alternatives ------------ The previous model for implementing this was the hooks system which is now deprecated. There may be ways to achieve this with user intervention (e.g. providing the credentials via metadata) but this would not be real automation and would assume that the user creating the instance has the ability to generate the enrollment credentials needed. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None to Openstack. This could pose a risk to the Identity Management if system administrative credentials are used for enrollment rather than an OTP. Even with OTP if these are collected from unbooted instances there may be some risk but these credentials by their nature should be limited to enrollment and one-time use so are of little value. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ If no driver is defined then there will be no impact. If a driver is defined then there will be a non-zero delay during the synchronous call to the Identity Management system. The amount of the delay will depend on how quickly the credentials can be generated and returned. This must be an accepted cost for the convenience of automatic enrollment. Other deployer impact --------------------- It is up to the user to position provisioning driver class into a place that can be found by the nova class loader. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rcritten Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- 1. Implement the provision driver base class 2. Add new configuration option to specify the class 3. Add a call to driver.get_credentials() and if there is a valid return value create a new tuple and add it to the injected_files list. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added to test: - get_credentials() returns a valid string - get_credentials() returns None - get_credentials() returns a non-string value - get_credentials() raising an exception Documentation Impact ==================== The new configuration option will need to be added. References ========== Hooks deprecated: * http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api/nova.hooks.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
crypto - Don't encrypt zero size object etags

There is no point encrypting the etag of a zero sized object since
the size metadata and the on disk file size reveal the content.
Not doing so avoids the overhead of wrapping a body key, and also
avoids having ciphertext (the encrypted etag) on disk for a known
plaintext (the etag of an empty string).

Change-Id: Idfd0a9a2a7e4a17f8b070f4a1e209c36b503494c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/32/316732/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from test.unit import FakeLogger, EMPTY_ETAG def test_PUT_zero_size_object(self): # object body encryption should be skipped for zero sized object body object_key = fetch_crypto_keys()['object'] plaintext_etag = EMPTY_ETAG env = {'REQUEST_METHOD': 'PUT', CRYPTO_KEY_CALLBACK: fetch_crypto_keys} hdrs = {'content-type': 'text/plain', 'content-length': '0', 'x-object-meta-etag': 'not to be confused with the Etag!', 'x-object-meta-test': 'encrypt me', 'x-object-sysmeta-test': 'do not encrypt me'} req = Request.blank( '/v1/a/c/o', environ=env, body='', headers=hdrs) self.app.register('PUT', '/v1/a/c/o', HTTPCreated, {}) resp = req.get_response(self.encrypter) self.assertEqual('201 Created', resp.status) self.assertEqual(plaintext_etag, resp.headers['Etag']) self.assertEqual(1, len(self.app.calls), self.app.calls) self.assertEqual('PUT', self.app.calls[0][0]) req_hdrs = self.app.headers[0] # verify that there is no body crypto meta self.assertNotIn('X-Object-Sysmeta-Crypto-Meta', req_hdrs) # verify etag is md5 of plaintext self.assertEqual(EMPTY_ETAG, req_hdrs['Etag']) # verify there is no etag crypto meta self.assertNotIn('X-Object-Sysmeta-Crypto-Etag', req_hdrs) # verify there is no container update override for etag self.assertNotIn( 'X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override-Etag', req_hdrs) # user meta is still encrypted self.assertEqual( base64.b64encode(encrypt('encrypt me', object_key, FAKE_IV)), req_hdrs['X-Object-Meta-Test']) actual = req_hdrs['X-Object-Transient-Sysmeta-Crypto-Meta-Test'] actual = json.loads(urllib.unquote_plus(actual)) self.assertEqual(Crypto().get_cipher(), actual['cipher']) self.assertEqual(FAKE_IV, base64.b64decode(actual['iv'])) self.assertEqual( base64.b64encode(encrypt('not to be confused with the Etag!', object_key, FAKE_IV)), req_hdrs['X-Object-Meta-Etag']) actual = req_hdrs['X-Object-Transient-Sysmeta-Crypto-Meta-Etag'] actual = json.loads(urllib.unquote_plus(actual)) self.assertEqual(Crypto().get_cipher(), actual['cipher']) self.assertEqual(FAKE_IV, base64.b64decode(actual['iv'])) # sysmeta is not encrypted self.assertEqual('do not encrypt me', req_hdrs['X-Object-Sysmeta-Test']) # verify object is empty by getting direct from the app get_req = Request.blank('/v1/a/c/o', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'GET'}) resp = get_req.get_response(self.app) self.assertEqual('', resp.body) self.assertEqual(EMPTY_ETAG, resp.headers['Etag'])

DIB: add libffi-dev to ansible element's build deps

Newer versions of paramiko (pulled in via ansible install)
now require libffi-dev to build.

Closes-bug: #1583321

commit_message:
Add some docs about firmware security

We don't want users to believe that ironic handles firmware security for
them, so document that we don't, and give some advice on how to do it.

This should be the start of a larger security document that talks about
firmwares, networks, ramdisk, more?

Co-authored-by: Devananda van der Veen <devananda.vdv@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I703b5d03da610fde43dd6723edd6cdc53051c1c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/78/308978/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _security: ======== Security ======== Overview ======== While Ironic is intended to be a secure application, it is important to note that it does not handle firmware security for a deployment. Deployers must properly evaluate their use case and take action to secure these items appropriately. TODO add a bunch of sources, maybe network security? Firmware security ================= When ironic deploys a server for a user, the user has full root access to the machine. Most servers in default settings do not prevent the root user from writing firmwares or accessing hardware such as the BMC or SPI interface. This means that a user could write malicious firmware before tearing down their instance, leaving future users of the machine vulnerable to attacks. A person deploying Ironic should work with their hardware vendor to secure firmwares via cryptographic signatures, disable OS access to interfaces that the user does not need (e.g. BMC), and choose proper BIOS settings to mitigate the risk of users writing firmware. ironic-python-agent supports custom hardware managers, which may have custom clean steps that run during automatic or manual cleaning. By creating a hardware manager that can validate firmware during cleaning, one can further mitigate the risk of a malicious firmware reaching the next user.

added_lines: def test_create_port_chain_with_flow_classifiers_basic_the_same(self): with self.port( name='test1' ) as port1, self.port( name='test2' ) as port2: with self.flow_classifier(flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port1['port']['id'] }) as fc1, self.flow_classifier(flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port2['port']['id'] }) as fc2: with self.port_pair_group(port_pair_group={}) as pg: self._test_create_port_chain({ 'flow_classifiers': [ fc1['flow_classifier']['id'], fc2['flow_classifier']['id'] ], 'port_pair_groups': [pg['port_pair_group']['id']] }) def test_create_multi_port_chain_with_flow_classifiers(self): with self.port( name='test1' ) as port: with self.flow_classifier(flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port['port']['id'] }) as fc1, self.flow_classifier(flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.101.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port['port']['id'] }) as fc2: with self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg1, self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg2: with self.port_chain( port_chain={ 'flow_classifiers': [ fc1['flow_classifier']['id'] ], 'port_pair_groups': [ pg1['port_pair_group']['id'] ] } ): self._test_create_port_chain({ 'flow_classifiers': [ fc2['flow_classifier']['id'] ], 'port_pair_groups': [pg2['port_pair_group']['id']] }) def test_create_multi_port_chain_with_conflict_flow_classifiers(self): with self.port( name='test1' ) as port1, self.port( name='test2' ) as port2: with self.flow_classifier(flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port1['port']['id'] }) as fc1, self.flow_classifier(flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port2['port']['id'] }) as fc2: with self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg1, self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg2: with self.port_chain( port_chain={ 'flow_classifiers': [ fc1['flow_classifier']['id'] ], 'port_pair_groups': [ pg1['port_pair_group']['id'] ] } ): self._create_port_chain( self.fmt, { 'flow_classifiers': [ fc2['flow_classifier']['id'] ], 'port_pair_groups': [ pg2['port_pair_group']['id'] ] }, expected_res_status=400 ) def test_update_port_chain_flow_classifiers(self): def test_update_port_chain_flow_classifiers_basic_the_same(self): with self.port( name='test1' ) as port1, self.port( name='test2' ) as port2: with self.flow_classifier( flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port1['port']['id'] } ) as fc1, self.flow_classifier( flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port2['port']['id'] } ) as fc2: with self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg: with self.port_chain(port_chain={ 'name': 'test1', 'description': 'desc1', 'port_pair_groups': [pg['port_pair_group']['id']], 'flow_classifiers': [fc1['flow_classifier']['id']] }) as pc: updates = { 'name': 'test2', 'description': 'desc2', 'flow_classifiers': [fc2['flow_classifier']['id']] } req = self.new_update_request( 'port_chains', {'port_chain': updates}, pc['port_chain']['id'] ) res = self.deserialize( self.fmt, req.get_response(self.ext_api) ) expected = pc['port_chain'] expected.update(updates) for k, v in six.iteritems(expected): self.assertEqual(res['port_chain'][k], v) req = self.new_show_request( 'port_chains', pc['port_chain']['id'] ) res = self.deserialize( self.fmt, req.get_response(self.ext_api) ) for k, v in six.iteritems(expected): self.assertEqual(res['port_chain'][k], v) def test_update_port_chain_conflict_flow_classifiers(self): with self.port( name='test1' ) as port1, self.port( name='test2' ) as port2: with self.flow_classifier( flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port1['port']['id'] } ) as fc1, self.flow_classifier( flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.101.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port1['port']['id'] } ) as fc2, self.flow_classifier( flow_classifier={ 'source_ip_prefix': '192.168.100.0/24', 'logical_source_port': port2['port']['id'] } ) as fc3: with self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg1, self.port_pair_group( port_pair_group={} ) as pg2: with self.port_chain(port_chain={ 'port_pair_groups': [pg1['port_pair_group']['id']], 'flow_classifiers': [fc1['flow_classifier']['id']] }), self.port_chain(port_chain={ 'name': 'test2', 'port_pair_groups': [pg2['port_pair_group']['id']], 'flow_classifiers': [fc2['flow_classifier']['id']] }) as pc2: updates = { 'flow_classifiers': [fc3['flow_classifier']['id']] } req = self.new_update_request( 'port_chains', {'port_chain': updates}, pc2['port_chain']['id'] ) res = req.get_response(self.ext_api) self.assertEqual(res.status_int, 400)

"}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2016-04-06 19:17:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/d9ee3d4262c93639308fee4c001cb77f25b741a0', 'message': "Move identity.backends.sql model code to sql_model.py

This patch moves identity.backends.sql model code to sql_model.py. The
sql model code (User, FederatedUser, LdapUser...) provides a model for
all identity backend drivers, not only sql. For example, shadow users
references the sql model to shadow federated (and eventually ldap)
users, but of course, doesn't need the sql driver.

And just to put another way, a user logins with ldap, we'll shadow the
user in sql via the sql model. It would be odd to reference the sql
driver backend when the ldap driver is the one being used.

In addition, I think it is a cleaner implementation to separate the
model from the driver.

Change-Id: I9bc44e0b9837bf5800dddd94bb36804c44581240

commit_message:
Move identity.backends.sql model code to sql_model.py

This patch moves identity.backends.sql model code to sql_model.py so
that they can be shared with the shadow users sql backend.

In addition, I think it is a cleaner implementation to separate the
model from the driver.

Change-Id: I9bc44e0b9837bf5800dddd94bb36804c44581240

added_lines: from keystone.identity.backends import model
deleted_lines: from keystone.identity.backends import sql as model

commit_message:
UI improvements for enroll node functionality

Removed headings for general, properties and extras node details.
Added new modal window for adding driver details. The button for this
is only activated once a driver is selected.

Currently adding all driver details is required to enable the enroll
node button as once enrolled, node and driver details cannot yet be
edited.

Change-Id: I2cf9fcb39fcb0e7973f7f99df57bda697da85bc7
