commit_message:
Declarative API Tests With Gabbi

The functional tests for the nova API reside primarily in what are
called the "api sample tests". These are a large collection of Python
test files that represent API requests paired with a large suite of
template files that represent expected JSON responses. There are
several problems with this setup (enumerated below) which can be
resolved by changing to using a declarative testing setup where
requests and responses reside in the same file and API server setup
is concise and centralized. This new setup will result in better
tests which are more capable of validating the existing API as well
as providing useful tooling for testing new APIs and resolving bugs.

Change-Id: I36d4a9465deefcd45febf25e96f7d6c36ad85674
Implements: blueprint gabbi-api-tests
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/52/291352/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Declarative API Tests With Gabbi ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/gabbi-api-tests The functional tests for the nova API reside primarily in what are called the "api sample tests". These are a large collection of Python test files that represent API requests paired with a large suite of template files that represent expected JSON responses. There are several problems with this setup (enumerated below) which can be resolved by changing to using a declarative testing setup where requests and responses reside in the same file and API server setup is concise and centralized. This new setup will result in better tests which are more capable of validating the existing API as well as providing useful tooling for testing new APIs and resolving bugs. Problem description =================== The api sample tests have a variety of problems, not least that they are inscrutable. Problems include: * HTTP requests (in Python code) are separated from expected responses (in template files). * Client requests don't resemble an HTTP request. * Templated responses don't resemble an actual HTTP response and limited in what they can validate. * Tests are slow, in part because service setup and teardown occurs for every test. * Setup, fixture and client code is sufficiently complex that it is hard to trust that test code itself is accurate and not introducing bugs. These problems are built into the design of the samples tests and not something that can be resolved by making slight adjustments. An entirely different approach is required. Use Cases --------- Developers want to be able to write API code that is easy to test and is tested reliably. End users and deployers want API code that can trust has been tested effectively. Proposed change =============== The different approach is to use `gabbi`_ a tool for testing HTTP APIs using a collection of YAML files that represent requests and expected responses. Gabbi integrates with the existing testing system, generating suites of tests that can run alongside existing functional tests. It directly accesses the nova WSGI applications and uses a real HTTP client to interact with the API. Existing fixture handling can be reused for persistence and other services. Here is a simple test, with keystone enabled, confirming that there are currently no servers:: tests: - name: list servers GET: /servers request_headers: x-auth-token: $ENVIRON['TOKEN'] status: 200 response_json_paths: $.servers: [] The request and response are in the same place, the details of the request are clear, and the expectations of the response are explicit and straightforward. Alternatives ------------ There are at least two alternatives that could be considered: * Continue using the api sample tests. This doesn't seem like a great option as apparently nobody likes or trusts them. * Use one of the API "frameworks" (e.g. `swagger`_) to simultaneously document and test the API. Such tools are great but they are designed for validating that the API is what you say it is, not for testing the use of HTTP in a service. Gabbi is explicitly about testing HTTP requests against arbitrary endpoints, especially in unexpected ways, making it easier to model the real world in tests. It also uses a format that cleanly corresponds with an HTTP request. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- No changes to the API, but we'll probably find some bugs in it. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- Better API. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- Developers will have a more effective tool for testing the nova API. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: snikitin Other contributors: cdent Work Items ---------- * Create a configuration fixture and initial test loader that will run the YAML files in a properly established environment. * As proof of the concept replace a small segment of api sample tests with YAML files (called gabbits in gabbi parlance). * Replace the rest of the api sample tests. Dependencies ============ The work has a dependency on `gabbi`_ itself. It is already in global requirements. Testing ======= The change will be replacing existing functional tests with new ones that use a different form. These tests will cover similar but not exactly the same scenarios. We will need to take extra care that we do not lose coverage in the process. Documentation Impact ==================== Devref documentation which describes how the new tests work and how to add more will need to be added. References ========== * Gabbi was initially designed to solve a problem in ceilometer: `Declarative HTTP API Tests`_ * It is now used in tests in `gnocchi`_, `aodh`_ and `ceilometer`_ as well as an `integration test`_ of nova, heat, aodh, gnocchi and ceilometer. * There was a `presentation`_ about gabbi at the Vancouver design summit. History ======= Optional section for Newton intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced .. _gabbi: https://gabbi.readthedocs.org/ .. _swagger: http://swagger.io/ .. _Declarative HTTP API Tests: http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/telemetry-specs/specs/kilo/declarative-http-tests.html .. _gnocchi: https://github.com/openstack/gnocchi/tree/master/gnocchi/tests/gabbi .. _aodh: https://github.com/openstack/aodh/tree/master/aodh/tests/functional/gabbi .. _ceilometer: https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/tree/master/ceilometer/tests/functional/gabbi .. _integration test: https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/tree/master/ceilometer/tests/integration .. _presentation: https://youtu.be/Xnx7SHsKGsc?t=1011

commit_message:
Keep BuildRequest db entry around longer

The lifetime of the BuildRequest db entry needs to be longer than it
currently is. As long as there is an InstanceMapping entry with a null
CellMapping the BuildRequest object may be needed for API requests. This
moves the removal of that db entry until after the InstanceMapping has
been updated to point at a cell, or removed.

Change-Id: I2b44ae9dfba4066bc7c9a92644e3782f76097c21
Partially-implements: bp add-buildrequest-obj

deleted_lines: # The BuildRequest needs to be stored until the instance is in # an instance table. At that point it will never be used again # and should be deleted. As instance creation is pushed back, # as noted above, this will move with it. # TODO(alaski): Sync API updates to the build_request to the # instance before it is destroyed. Right now only locked_by can # be updated before this is destroyed. build_request.destroy()

commit_message:
Drop fields from BuildRequest object and model

Now that there's a serialized instance object on the BuildRequest object
and in the build_requests table a lot of fields/columns are no longer
necessary. To prepare for removal of the columns from the db at a later
time references to them have been removed. This starts a deprecation
timer so that they can be removed in Ocata at the earliest.

Note that the BuildRequest object was never passed over the wire, and is
just created and immediately destroyed at this point so there is no need
to handle backwards compatibility for these changes.

Change-Id: Ie86ba66d5f73c153b68bef83661d4c8bdb0ae9dc

commit_message:
Pass OS_DEBUG to the tox test environment

The StandardLogging fixture defaults to log level INFO and has
the ability to log at level DEBUG if the OS_DEBUG environment
variable is set to a true value. Let tox copy OS_DEBUG to the
test environment to allow debug log capture for a command line
like:

  OS_DEBUG=True tox -epy27

Change-Id: Ibe51653f652c99aee56f702be571130cbb7f913d

commit_message:
Fix resize to same host failed using anti-affinity group

ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter selects host which is not in in the
hosts of the members of the group. An instance does not have
anti-affinity with itself.
The current code has problem when select hosts, the instance's
current host will be filtered out by ServerGroupAntiAffinityFilter.
This can lead to failure when resize an instance with anti-affinity
group to the same host.

In this patch, ServerGroupAntiAffinityFite is modified.

Change-Id: Ie016f59f5b98bb9c70b3e33556bd747f79fc77bd
Closes-Bug:#1558532

Remove mox used in tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_server_start_stop

tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_server_start_stop

commit_message:
libvirt: add method to configure max downtime when migrating

In order to clean direct to call to libvirt and stay coherent with the
purpose of Guest's object, this commit introduces a method
"configure_downtime" which is basically a simple decorator to the one
from libvirt.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-clean-driver
Change-Id: I0ba96c90639079517a4430778d56366e40fe855f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/39/250739/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def migrate_configure_max_downtime(self, mstime): """Sets maximun time for which domain is allowed to be paused :param mstime: Downtime is ms. """ self._domain.migrateSetMaxDowntime(mstime)

subject: Libvirt: Fix SMBFS volume attach race condition
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-02 14:53:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f46754cbad4d3a9bf558d377c698b50de15161f3', 'message': 'Libvirt: Fix SMBFS volume attach race condition

When the SMBFS volume backend is used and a volume is detached,
the according SMB share is unmounted if no longer used.

This can cause issues if at the same time, a different volume
stored on the same share is being attached as the according
disk image will not be available.

This patch fixes the issue by using one mount point per volume.

Note that synchronizing the connect_volume and disconnect_volume
methods would not prevent this issue. For example, even if the
connect_volume method finishes its execution, the volume might
still not be attached to the instance by the time disconnect_volume
is called targeting another volume from the same share.

Change-Id: I7a150bcefa17c7cd36ff5bb1be0bc42c3341a44f
Closes-Bug: #1461081
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-11 17:27:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/177e1b91c6faa51542a3e72457c3ee9c68c87653', 'message': 'Libvirt: Fix SMBFS volume attach race condition

When the SMBFS volume backend is used and a volume is detached,
the according SMB share is unmounted if no longer used.

This can cause issues if at the same time, a different volume
stored on the same share is being attached as the according

commit_message:
Libvirt: Fix SMBFS volume attach race condition

When the SMBFS volume backend is used and a volume is detached,
the according SMB share is unmounted if no longer used.

This can cause issues if at the same time, a different volume
stored on the same share is being attached as the according
disk image will not be available.

This patch fixes the issue by tracking share usage.

Note that this issue does not occure in case of already attached
volumes as there will be locks in place, preventing the unmount
operation. For the same reason, if the service is restarted, we
are not affected if the cached information is lost.

At the moment, we apply this patch on the Cinder CI as without it,
some Tempest test fail.

Closes-Bug: #1461081

Change-Id: I7a150bcefa17c7cd36ff5bb1be0bc42c3341a44f

commit_message:
Mount /var/lib/rabbitmq into the Rabbitmq container

The field hostPath specifies what directory on the host to mount
into the container. Rabbitmq should use /var/lib/mysql from the
host since that's the expected location for rabbitmq's data.

Change-Id: I6eb04ce38a1c8959a035cb4ec55d505492dd158e
Partially-implements: blueprint openstack-serivces

in a pod.

Each service will have its own configmap since each service
Glance service has a unique config file.  We want to make
sure every service has its own configmap so that when we
reconfigure, only the necessary services get restarted.

commit_message:
Fix Glance configmap reference

The CLI is going to look for config based on the services
in a pod.

Each service will have its own configmap since each service
Glance service has a unique config file.  We want to make
sure every service has its own configmap so that when we
reconfigure, only the necessary services get restarted.

Make sure that glance-api mounts /var/lib/glance.

Change-Id: I25a404b9832f1d7c17447501a00bd36ce4e39dad
Closes-bug: #1584363
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/86/319586/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: LOG.info('List zone recordsets') _, body = self.client.list_recordset(zone['id']) self.assertGreater(len(body), 0) def test_list_zones_recordsets(self): LOG.info('Create a zone') _, zone1 = self.zone_client.create_zone() self.addCleanup(self.zone_client.delete_zone, zone1['id']) LOG.info('Create another zone') _, zone2 = self.zone_client.create_zone() self.addCleanup(self.zone_client.delete_zone, zone2['id']) LOG.info('List recordsets') _, body = self.client.list_zones_recordsets() self.assertGreater(len(body['recordsets']), 0) def test_list_filter_zones_recordsets(self): LOG.info('Create a zone') _, zone1 = self.zone_client.create_zone() self.addCleanup(self.zone_client.delete_zone, zone1['id']) recordset_data = { "name": zone1['name'], "description": "This is an example record set.", "type": "A", "ttl": 3600, "records": [ "10.1.0.2" ] } LOG.info('Create a Recordset') resp, zone1_recordset = self.client.create_recordset(zone1['id'], recordset_data) LOG.info('Create another zone') _, zone2 = self.zone_client.create_zone() self.addCleanup(self.zone_client.delete_zone, zone2['id']) LOG.info('List recordsets') _, body = self.client.list_zones_recordsets(params={"data": "10.1.*"}) recordsets = body['recordsets'] self.assertEqual(zone1_recordset['id'], recordsets[0]['id'])

commit_message:
libvirt: add "abort_job" to Guest's object

In order to clean direct to call to libvirt and stay coherent with the
purpose of Guest's object, this commit introduces a method "abort_job"
which is basically a simple decorator to the one from libvirt.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-clean-driver
Change-Id: I3369247212b3f60b8f28d62522276e7686fad5de

commit_message:
CLI support for services with more complex pods

Nova has a more complex pod structure that it requires
a pod definition or order to determine how the CLI will
find the service config file.

Change-Id: I59f00b1ad22a337782b7751cff5b75fc7beb096c
Partially-implements: blueprint kolla-kubernetes-cli

added_lines: def get_service_config_files(service_name): directory = os.path.join('/etc/kolla/', service_name)

commit_message:
Mount /var/lib/mysql into the Mariadb container

The field hostPath specifies what directory on the host to mount
into the container.  Mariadb should use /var/lib/mysql from the
host since that's the expected location for mariadb's data.

Change-Id: I9b6510731021a33e8a78e2ce6773d5b34a9c3695
Partially-implements: blueprint openstack-serivces

added_lines: name: mariadb-bootstrap - mountPath: /var/log/kolla path: /var/lib/mysql

subject: Windows iSCSI: properly handle config option
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-20 09:54:39.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/windows/test_windows.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/windows/windows.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e4134f535556d7f3a9e43cf5195d52f702c9dc1a', 'message': "Windows iSCSI: properly handle config option

The Windows iSCSI driver attempts to use the 'image_conversion_dir'
option from the configuration object passed by the manager, without
registering it again.

The issue is that by the driver is loaded, the copy of the global
CONF object will not contain this option. When the module containing
this option is imported, it gets registered under the global CONF
object, so the driver will not be able to fetch it this way.

For this reason, operations involving volume upload will fail.

This can easily be fixed by just using CONF.image_conversion_dir,
since there's no code that expects this option to be defined per
backend.

Change-Id: Icf5af04dc431e44d7ce332bf8c2fb9b0a55cdc9a
Closes-Bug: #1583993
"}]
commit_message:
Windows iSCSI: properly handle config option

The Windows iSCSI driver attempts to use the 'image_conversion_dir'
option from the configuration object passed by the manager, without
registering it again.

The issue is that by the driver is loaded, the copy of the global
CONF object will not contain this option. When the module containing
this option is imported, it gets registered under the global CONF
object, so the driver will not be able to fetch it this way.

For this reason, operations involving volume upload will fail.

This can easily be fixed by just using CONF.image_conversion_dir,
since there's no code that expects this option to be defined per
backend.

Change-Id: Icf5af04dc431e44d7ce332bf8c2fb9b0a55cdc9a
Closes-Bug: #1583993
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/70/319170/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: temp_vhd_path = os.path.join(CONF.image_conversion_dir,

subject: sort version numbers as we display them
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-18 20:03:31.000000000', 'files': ['deliverables/_independent/openstack-ansible.yaml', 'README.rst', 'openstack_releases/sphinxext.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/commit/5dd5162e8549c53daec0aff1aa79bd562e8dc27b', 'message': "sort version numbers as we display them

We have been relying on folks adding entries to the deliverable files in
release order. That breaks the scripts that actually prepare the
releases, since those scripts only look at the last entry in each file
and releasing a stable version of an independent project often means
inserting an entry into the middle of the deliverable file.

This change tries to sort the versions in the deliverable files as it
reads them before building any tables. We use a tuple of the parts of
the version string, converted to integers where possible to avoid weird
alphabetical sorting of numbers and because SemanticVersion can't always
parse some of the legacy version tags project teams used.

The patch includes one change to an existing deliverable file to
demonstrate that the output is sorted properly.

Change-Id: I962a38db6ca79be02a3fdc8d387e30ee86a6a61c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
"}]
commit_message:
sort version numbers as we display them

We have been relying on folks adding entries to the deliverable files in
release order. That breaks the scripts that actually prepare the
releases, since those scripts only look at the last entry in each file
and releasing a stable version of an independent project often means
inserting an entry into the middle of the deliverable file.

This change tries to sort the versions in the deliverable files as it
reads them before building any tables. We use a tuple of the parts of
the version string, converted to integers where possible to avoid weird
alphabetical sorting of numbers and because SemanticVersion can't always
parse some of the legacy version tags project teams used.

The patch includes one change to an existing deliverable file to
demonstrate that the output is sorted properly.

Change-Id: I962a38db6ca79be02a3fdc8d387e30ee86a6a61c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/15/318315/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pbr.versiondef _version_sort_key(release): """Return a value we can compare for sorting. We can't just use SemanticVersion instances because some of the legacy tags don't comply with the parser. Use a tuple of the parts of the version string, converted to integers where possible to avoid weird alphabetical sorting of numbers. """ key = [] for p in str(release['version']).split('.'): try: key.append(int(p)) except ValueError: key.append(p) return tuple(key) sorted_releases = sorted( info.get('releases', []), key=_version_sort_key, ) for r in reversed(sorted_releases):
deleted_lines: import pbr for r in reversed(info.get('releases', [])):

clean up independent project listsinggs

Move the independent section on the main page above the team list to
make it easier to find.

commit_message:
Remove unused logging import and LOG global var

In some modules the global LOG is not used any more. And the import
of logging is not used. This patch removes the unused logging import
and LOG vars.

Co-Authored-By: ChangBo Guo(gcb) <eric.guo@easystack.cn>
Change-Id: Ia72f99688ce00aeecca9239f9ef123611259a2fa

commit_message:
Add support for dry-run and noop deployment for deploy changes commands

This commit adds an additional options to fuel client to support
dry-run and noop modes of deployment which are really useful for
debugging and day-to day operations and life cycle management of
clusters

Partial-bug: #1569839

Change-Id: I77d0a8257a97a9f40e3cfd1a630c95b7800fe1e6

deleted_lines: def deploy_changes(self, environment_id): deploy_task = env.deploy_changes() def redeploy_changes(self, environment_id): redeploy_task = env.redeploy_changes()

commit_message:
[Docs][Verify] Adding page for `rally verify` [part 1]

Adding docs for the following 'verify' commands:

1. `rally verify install/uninstall/reinstall`
2. `rally verify genconfig/showconfig`
3. `rally verify start`

Change-Id: Ib44e1789d6a8deb5fddc1a33343109d37dd3affe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/25/280025/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2016 Mirantis Inc. All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. .. _tutorial_step_10_cloud_verification: Step 10. Cloud verification =========================== .. contents:: :local: In this step, we’re going to look at how to use Tempest and Rally. We assume that you have a :ref:`Rally installation <tutorial_step_0_installation>` and an already :ref:`registered OpenStack deployment <tutorial_step_1_setting_up_env_and_running_benchmark_from_samples>` in Rally. So let's get started! Tempest installation -------------------- In order to install Tempest just execute the following command: .. code-block:: console $ rally verify install ... By default the command clones Tempest from the *https://git.openstack.org/openstack/tempest* repository and installs it for the current deployment. But we can install Tempest for any registered deployment in Rally, using the *--deployment** argument. .. code-block:: console $ rally verify install --deployment <UUID or name of a deployment> ... Also Rally allows us to specify a source to clone Tempest from. The source can be both the path to a local Tempest repository and an URL, for example, to some GitHub repository. .. code-block:: console $ rally verify install --source <Path/URL to repo to clone Tempest from> ... Finally, we can specify the *--system-wide* parameter that will tell Rally not to create a virtual environment for Tempest. In this case it is assumed that all Tempest requirements are already installed in the local environment. .. code-block:: console $ rally verify install --system-wide ... Tempest config generation ------------------------- In order to generate Tempest config file just execute the following command: .. code-block:: console $ rally verify genconfig ... By default the command generates a config file for the current deployment, but we can generate the config file for any registered deployment in Rally, using the *--deployment** argument. .. code-block:: console $ rally verify genconfig --deployment <UUID or name of a deployment> ... Also Rally allows us to specify any local path to the config file, for example, */home/ubuntu/tempest.conf*, and in this case Rally will generate the *tempest.conf* file in the */home/ubuntu/* directory. .. code-block:: console $ rally verify genconfig --tempest-config <User-specified Tempest config file location> ... Moreover, we can override the existing Tempest config file by providing the *--override* parameter in the *rally verify genconfig* command: .. code-block:: console $ rally verify genconfig --override ... In order to see the generated config file just execute the following command: .. code-block:: console $ rally verify showconfig ... To see the generated config file for a certain deployment specify the *--deployment** argument. .. code-block:: console $ rally verify showconfig --deployment <UUID or name of a deployment> ... Run verification ----------------

commit_message:
show release:cycle-trailing projects separately

Group the projects that trail the release cycle separately from the
other projects, rather than including them in the proper "type"
sections.

Change-Id: I97c209151a91ff5a18683c883ebca41c5386ff5c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
remove reviewer instructions for upper-constraints.txt

We no longer require the submitter to also patch upper-constraints.txt,
so don't require the reviewer to look for those patches.

Change-Id: Iebc7a4bdc69b8f2fc75e0b32cfd1e0f384e75627
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/82/318882/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: * Make sure there is a requirements update patch to enable use of the new release. With the constraints system in place, releasing a library is no longer sufficient to cause it to be used in the CI systems. We must explicitly update the constraints file for integration tests, and we want to ensure that the lower bounds accurately reflect the versions needed to provide features for the consuming applications. This latter step is difficult to do accurately via a script, so we need it to be done by the person releasing the library.

commit_message:
verify that a release request includes all of the repositories

Ensure that a release request for the current release cycle includes
all of the repositories for the deliverable, and no extras.

Change-Id: Ifc6f0c7e773618b8d8b96ceb83eec1cc65133063
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/38/318338/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Some rules only apply to the most current release. if series_name != defaults.RELEASE: continue # Rules for only the current release cycle. final_release = deliverable_info['releases'][-1] deliverable_name = os.path.basename(filename)[:-5] # strip .yaml expected_repos = set( r.name for r in governance.get_repositories( team_data, deliverable_name=deliverable_name, ) ) if not expected_repos: msg = ('unable to find deliverable %s in the governance list' % deliverable_name) print(msg) errors.append(msg) actual_repos = set( p['repo'] for p in final_release.get('projects', []) ) for extra in actual_repos.difference(expected_repos): msg = ( '%s release %s includes repository %s ' 'that is not in the governance list' % (filename, final_release['version'], extra) ) print(msg) errors.append(msg) for missing in expected_repos.difference(actual_repos): msg = ( '%s release %s is missing %s from the governance list' % (filename, final_release['version'], missing) ) print(msg) errors.append(msg)

commit_message:
Get rid of check_wrong_config test

There was a list of hardcoded services that allow us to use
service-reconfiguration. Now there is no strict limitation
on services that could be configured with this feature.
This mean that test check_wrong_config is deprecated and should be
deleted

Change-Id: I729bf0235eea525cc0464346ca791ca7733e5de9
Related-Bug: #1580522
Closes-bug: #1584693

Check Nailgun response Snapshot: check_wrong_config """ self.show_step(1, initialize=True) self.env.revert_snapshot("basic_env_for_reconfiguration") self.show_step(2) self.show_step(3) cluster_id = self.fuel_web.get_last_created_cluster() config = {'cinder_config': {'foo': {'value': 'bar'}}} err_msg = 'A wrong configuration was applied' expected_code = 400 self.check_response_code(expected_code, err_msg, self.fuel_web.client.upload_configuration, config, cluster_id) self.env.make_snapshot("check_wrong_config") @test(depends_on_groups=['basic_env_for_reconfiguration'], groups=["services_reconfiguration_thread_2",

commit_message:
Fix uses of fetch method from nova.virt.images

Change 059021550a22ddff731836a23a6b187ef1c19ad0 in nova removed
user_id and project_id arguments from the fetch() function defined
in nova.virt.images .

This change needs to also be reflected in compute-hyperv.

Change-Id: I0d965176dbde08b31eb4654fce810da82601ac98
Closes-Bug: #1583229

subject: Disable VIPs before stopping cluster during version upgrade
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-04 11:21:26.000000000', 'files': ['extraconfig/tasks/major_upgrade_controller_pacemaker_2.sh', 'extraconfig/tasks/major_upgrade_controller_pacemaker_1.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/33b5bb61fe102fc55cb82fc73b852db03419c45b', 'message': 'Disable VIPs before stopping cluster during version upgrade

If "pcs cluster stop --all" is executed on a controller that
happens to have a VIP on the internal network, pcs may use the
VIP as the source address for communication with another cluster
node.  When pacemaker is stopped this VIP goes away, and pcs never
receives a response from the other node.  This causes pcs to hang
indefinitely; eventually the upgrade times out and fails.

Disabling the VIPs before stopping the cluster avoids this
situation.

Change-Id: I6bc59120211af28456018640033ce3763c373bbb
Closes-Bug: 1577570
(cherry picked from commit 6e65c8fc0a3c2b4025b08d1a2c8b03696e8fb7f6)
'}]
commit_message:
Disable VIPs before stopping cluster during version upgrade

If "pcs cluster stop --all" is executed on a controller that
happens to have a VIP on the internal network, pcs may use the
VIP as the source address for communication with another cluster
node.  When pacemaker is stopped this VIP goes away, and pcs never
receives a response from the other node.  This causes pcs to hang
indefinitely; eventually the upgrade times out and fails.

Disabling the VIPs before stopping the cluster avoids this
situation.

Change-Id: I6bc59120211af28456018640033ce3763c373bbb
Closes-Bug: 1577570
(cherry picked from commit 6e65c8fc0a3c2b4025b08d1a2c8b03696e8fb7f6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/55/312455/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Disable all VIPs before stopping the cluster, so that pcs doesn't use one as a source address: # https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1330688 for vip in $(pcs resource show | grep ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2 | grep Started | awk '{ print $1 }'); do pcs resource disable $vip check_resource $vip stopped 60 done

subject: devstack: Configure console device name
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-20 10:32:31.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/lib/ironic'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/b6962184186987b80005c2ee26e1a514dcc9c2c1', 'message': "devstack: Configure console device name

Console device name is hardcoded to ttyS0 in ironic devstack plugin.
On some architecture, serial device name may not be ttyS0. For example,
ttyAMA0 for ARM.

This patch adds parameter IRONIC_TTY_DEV to configure console device
name, and keeps using ttyS0 if it's not set.

Closes-Bug: #1582564

Change-Id: I13c67e2c5d573c5b79776746e08a84c60861d6a7
Signed-off-by: Yibo Cai <yibo.cai@linaro.org>

commit_message:
devstack: Configure console device name

Console device name is hardcoded to ttyS0 in ironic devstack plugin.
On some architecture, serial device name may not be ttyS0. For example,
ttyAMA0 for ARM.

This patch adds parameter IRONIC_TTY_DEV to configure console device
name, and keeps using ttyS0 if it's not set.

Closes-Bug: #1582564

Change-Id: I13c67e2c5d573c5b79776746e08a84c60861d6a7
Signed-off-by: Yibo Cai <yibo.cai@linaro.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/84/319184/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IRONIC_TTY_DEV=${IRONIC_TTY_DEV:-ttyS0} local pxe_params="nofb nomodeset vga=normal console=${IRONIC_TTY_DEV}"

commit_message:
Add a lock() context manager to image backend

Add a context manager which holds a lock on a disk during its context.
This patch doesn't add a use of this interface, but it is used
extensively in the following series.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-instance-storage

Change-Id: Id9d469ac56ad61ff8273179c0edbf8a31f716e89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/279625/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_concurrency import lockutils self.locked = False @contextlib.contextmanager def lock(self): # We protect here against re-entrance. We assume that this object # isn't shared between multiple threads. The actual lock is # independent of this object, so multiple threads/processes is safe # as long as each has their own object. if self.locked: yield else: lock_name = os.path.basename(self.path) # This MUST be compatible with the lock used by # nova.utils.synchronized(). # NOTE(mdbooth): Ideally there would be a way create a context # manager which uses nova.utils.synchronized directly. # Unfortunately I can't find one. with lockutils.lock(lock_name, lock_file_prefix='nova-', external=True, lock_path=self.lock_path): self.locked = True try: yield finally: self.locked = False

commit_message:
Fix "Codec can't encode characters"

Headers were encoded in HTTPClient, but when glance client started
to use SessionClient this functionality was lost.

This commit replaces static method "encode_headers" from HTTPClient
and makes it a common function, that SessionClient can use when
converting image meta to headers.


Change-Id: If9f8020220d2a0431b4241b38b9c83c09c0d75cb
Closes-bug: #1574587
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient refs/changes/54/316054/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
task-based: fix 'SerializedTasks' API handler

SerializedTasks API handler used to call serializers for < 9.0 envs. For
9.0 envs and above, it must call LCM serializers. This patch fixes that
issue, and now the API handler returns serialized tasks using appropriate
serializers.

Change-Id: I88e36b55fc5fcb9742cf48dc2e1e539bab1bf35a
Closes-Bug: #1581819
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/33/319833/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nailgun import constsfrom nailgun.task import task if objects.Release.is_lcm_supported(cluster.release): return objects.Cluster.get_nodes_not_for_deletion(cluster).all() try: if objects.Release.is_lcm_supported(cluster.release): # in order to do not repeat quite complex logic, we create # a temporary task (transaction) instance and pass it to # task_deploy serializer. transaction = objects.Transaction.model( name=consts.TASK_NAMES.deployment, cluster=cluster) rv = task.ClusterTransaction.task_deploy( transaction, objects.Cluster.get_deployment_tasks(cluster, graph_type), nodes, selected_task_ids=task_ids) objects.Transaction.delete(transaction) return rv # for old clusters we have to fallback to old serializers

commit_message:
Open up firewall for ironic provisioning

Ironic requires additional ports to be open.
    TCP ports: 6385 & 9999
    UDP ports: 53 & 54

If Ironic is enabled, open the ports

Change-Id: I9a1cf8aab959b926f7f853208a4f54658e24e07e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/68/315268/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nova secgroup-add-rule $NOVA_USER tcp 6385 6385 0.0.0.0/0 nova secgroup-add-rule $NOVA_USER tcp 9999 9999 0.0.0.0/0 nova secgroup-add-rule $NOVA_USER udp 53 53 0.0.0.0/0 nova secgroup-add-rule $NOVA_USER udp 54 54 0.0.0.0/0
